text:
WOW! Super-fantastic! We LOVED this chicken dish! I used marinated artichokes and chopped them fine (I believe they added to the overall flavor). I used 1.5t minced garlic and a dash of salt and pepper in place of the garlic pepper (I didn't have any). I completely drained the artichokes but still ended up with some liquid in the pan (I'm puzzled where it came from), but it may have helped to flavor the chicken. Company-worthy or a nice change of pace for everyday fare. Excellent post!

01/10/05 - Made this AGAIN and realized that the water is definitely coming from the artichokes. I squeezed them before chopping and extracted a lot more liquid. You simply got to use marinated artichokes to capture that extra flavor! We also sliced the chicken breasts into strips, and added 5 pieces of precooked bacon (heated & crumbled) to the artichoke mixture. Simply FANTASTIC! I've NEVER rated a recipe twice - this is that good!! Just drain and squeeze the artichokes and your water problem will disappear!

text:
I hate to change my prior five-star rating to a four-star, but the first time I made this I subbed half the mayo with sour cream. I just made this as-writte, with the full amount mayo, and it's really really oily, and leaves an aftertaste.  I still love this recipe and will  make it again, but you really need to swap out some of the mayo for sour cream. With that change, it's fabulous. Once again, thanks for sharing :)

text:
This was so good! I did make a few changes: I was cooking for 6 and used 8oz fat free sour cream, 1/2c light Hellmans mayo, 1c shredded parm. I also sauteed in 1 Tbs. butter: 3 large garlic cloves (minced) with an 8oz jar of mushrooms (drained and chopped.) I let the mushroom mixture cool and then mixed the ingredients as in recipe. I did use marinated artichokes as others suggested. I also sprinkled a little Italian Bread Crumbs over the top and then sprayed with Butter cooking spray to get it to "crisp the top" I baked mine for 40 minutes in a 375 oven. I served the chicken on top of whole wheat egg noodles. Juicey, Tastey....no left overs!!!!

city:

country:

text:
This was fantastic.
We caramelized 1/2 onion in 3 tbsps of olive oil and a 1/4 tsp. of red pepper flakes. We removed the onion and then sauteed a 1/2 pound of fresh sliced mushrooms with 3 cloves of minced garlic. We halved  two chicken breasts thickness wise to make four breast servings. We buttered a shallow glass baking dish and layered the bottom of the dish with a bag of pre washed baby spinach. We placed the halved breast on top of the layer of spinach and topped each breast with caramelized onions and mushrooms. We drained two 12 oz. jars of marinated artichokes reserving a 1/4 cup of the marinade. We drizzled the reserved marinade over the spinach, breasts, caramelized onions and mushrooms. We then covered each breast with the recipe mixture of mayo, parmesan cheese, marinated artichokes and garlic pepper. Lastly, we VERY LIGHTLY sprinkled cayenne pepper over the dish. Baked at 375 for 50 minutes or until the topping is golden. OUT OF THIS WORLD!!!

text:
I've been making this recipe for years, having gotten it from my mom. I don't change a thing and can't imagine why anyone would want to. It has never failed to receive rave reviews and my guests think I spent hours in the kitchen. There is so much flavor that it needs to be served with a simple salad with a light tasting dressing like Newman's olive oil & vinegar, and some fresh asparagus and yum, yum, yummo. I've used the powdered parmesean in a pinch and it's still good. If you're needing all that change, perhaps it's your choice of mayonnaise. The salt/pepper should go directly on the chicken before pouring over the topping.

text:
I got a similar recipe a couple of years ago from Taste of Home magazine and it is fabulous. My neighbor/friend loves to be invited to dinner when I make this. I pound the chicken before topping it with the artichoke mixture. This not only tenderizes the chicken but it increases the surface for all the yummy topping. I use garlic powder instead of garlic pepper. And don't forget to season the chicken with salt and pepper before putting the topping on. Give this recipe a try. You’ll love it, especially if you like artichoke dip.

text:
A little on the rich side.  But that didn't stop me from enjoying it.  I just had to eat it in a smaller dose than usual!  It was a great foundation recipe, but for my tastes it needed some doctoring up. First, I knew straight mayo would be a little much for me so, just as I do with my artichoke dip,  I cut it back a little and mellowed it out by replacing some of the mayo with softened cream cheese.  I also prettied it up with some chopped, wilted fresh spinach, finely chopped red bell pepper and mushrooms, and added just a teeny bit of minced garlic, Worcestershire and hot sauce. The additions gave it some much needed pizzazz and dimension in flavor as well as color, and contributed greatly to a nice presentation. Baking time was just right for perfectly cooked and deliciously tender meat.  Not sure I'd make this again, however, as it was a little heavy and rich for me and as written needs some work to elevate it above "just average."

text:
Ok, I had to review this because DH actually asked for the leftovers!! He is not big on leftovers, but was disappointed I hadn't sent the rest to work the next day (I didn't think it would microwave well). I did as others suggest and used 1/2 mayo and 1/2 sour cream. I also added mushrooms and black olives, and used 1/2 cup Parmesan and 1/2 cup of a shredded Italian cheese blend. I used chicken breast tenders, next time I think I'll brown the chicken before adding the sauce just for looks, may try spinach also. Served once with brown rice and again with whole wheat spaghetti. UPDATE: I now saute the chicken strips 1st in olive oil and garlic, then top witht he sauce, to which I've added spinach to and use 1/2 mayo and 1/2 sour cream. I top it with bread crumbs mixed w/ olive oil! Looks great and DH loves it! A regular on my menu!

text:
This chicken is good.  I made this because my boyfriend and I love artichoke and we had a jar of the marinated stuff in the fridge to eat up.  I halved the recipe as it was just him and I and served with rice and caesar salad (with the bf's homemade dressing).  I made the following changes: 1) marinated artichokes, drained and squeezed and diced. 2) powdered parmesan (it's all I had) and a little bit of grated jalepeno-havarti for flavour 3) miracle whip brand mayonnaise (reduced calorie) 4) a little salt, pepper and garlic spice directly on the chicken before the mixture.  Cooking time was slightly longer but my chicken breasts might have still been a bit frozen.  Sprinkled with cayanne and paprika like some people recommended.  Overall meal was nice for a change.  I wouldn't give it 5 stars even without the changes only because I wouldn't call it the MOST FLAVOURFUL chicken of my life.

text:
A nice evening's dinner choice that, interestingly enough, made the most impact on our 6 year old who gobbled it down and pronounced it delicious. He has never called chicken delicious before so that was a rather interesting aside. We made no substitutions because I have always had great luck cooking chicken in mayonaise.  The sauce/topping was very good and worked well with the mildness of the chicken.  The only problem was the timing given (30 Minutes) is IMPOSSIBLE-it just cannot be correct unless you have parboiled the chicken first. We cooked ours for 1 hour 15 minutes and the chicken was still a ligh pink in areas.  My thought here is that there is a significant enough mass used as a topping that 30 minutes was just not nearly enough time to cook the chicken properly.  Keep this in mind! At 30 minutes, our chicken was completely raw underneath the artichoke.

Delish but made a few changes.  I added 1 tablespoon of lemon juice to the mayo mixture and I browned the chicken breasts first in a pan, adding a bit of vinegar 1-2 Tbsp. to the pan to deglaze it after they were brown.  I added this glaze to the mayo and baked uncovered until the surface started to turn golden.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I made this with 1/2 cup mayo and 1/2 cup sour cream and almost a cup of Parmesan. First, I sautéed about 4oz button mushrooms in butter until brown. Then added drained and chopped artichoke hearts and 2 cloves minced garlic and sautéed for another minute. I let this cool quite bit before stirring it into the mayo/sour cream/cheese mixture. I cut my chicken breaks into strips and put them into a casserole dish that was just the right size so they were touching and salted and peppered them. Then I spread the artichoke mixture on top. I crushed some crackers and mixed with melted butter and sprinkled on top. Baked at 375 for 30 minutes. Served chicken and sauce over linguine. Fantastic!

Table for Two

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is really very good and quite easy! I used Reese's marinated quartered artichoke hearts which I drained and then squeezed out the excess liquids. I had only shredded parmesan (rather than grated) on hand, used Duke's mayo from Central Market (I think it's the best) and substituted sour cream for half of the mayo. I used 1 clove of garlic (about 1.5 teaspoons), and some pepper in lieu of the garlic pepper. With it being only the two of us, I used 2 large chicken breasts which I cut into 2" strips lengthwise and for a prettier presentation (and also for taste), I dredged the strips in flour and browned them slightly in olive oil before baking. I thought the artichoke mixture was a perfect amount for 2 chicken breasts.  I served this atop capellini with a small side salad. What a quick and delightful meal! Thank you Amanda!

userID:

Display Name:
maisonpink

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Recipe as-is deserves 4 stars, 5 stars with recommended changes from reviewers.    The first time I made this recipe, it was as instructed.  The chicken came out perfectly cooked and the topping was delicious, but i felt it wasn't living up to it's full flavor potential.  The second time I made this recipe I used marinated artichoke hearts, reserving the liquid to use as a marinade for the chicken (marinated about 30 mins, but more would be great), used regular pepper and chopped garlic (1-2 cloves) instead of garlic pepper, and used half sour cream/half mayo.  I also drizzled the chicken and topping with a few tablespoons of the reserved artichoke marinade just before popping in the oven and lightly sprinkled everything with cayenne pepper.  30 minutes was the perfect cook time for me using regular boneless chicken breasts.  I did hit them with the broiler for about 2 minutes at the end to add some nice color.    These changes really packed a powerful flavor punch and the dish was a hit with my family.  The artichoke mixture was actually a hit immediately after it was mixed up as my father tasted some on crackers and said it would be a fabulous dip.    This recipe was also super simple to mix up and was in the oven in less than five minutes, after marinating time.  Everything could easily be made up ahead of time and combined just before cooking.  Really delicious.  A must try that is good for family and company.    Recipe doubles very well.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
In an attempt to tidy up my recipe box I realized there are some recipes that I have overlooked. That's what happens when your recipe box is bursting with more than a couple of thousand saved items. So, I finally made this chicken dish served with Garlic Spinach (AR) and it made for a delicious meal. There is absolutely no exaggeration in the quoted 35 minute prep and cook time, allowing this dish to be enjoyed any day of the week. I used marinated artichokes and used half mayo/sour cream. A reviewer had suggested toasting some Panko crumbs and sprinkling them on top. I might add that the next time. I was very careful to drain and even press excess liquid from the artichokes but still had a small amount of water in the baking dish described by some reviewrs. I say "just never mind" as it in no way took away from the taste and texture. I would suggest that the Parmesan cheese be of the best brand affordable or at least freshly grated. I'm pointing this out as the flavour of the cheese comes through in just the most perfect balance and therefore this might be where to spend a little extra if possible. At first I cringed at the price of a fairly small piece but it really lasts when stored correctly. Thanks for posting a great recipe.

I have been making this for years now...I don't use measurements, just make it according to how many chicken breasts I use. Like another reveiwer, I can't imagine changing this recipe beyond a little personal tweeking since it's 1st rate as it's written. I get rave reviews and get asked for the recipe all the time and I make this at least once a week. I've also used this sauce over boneless pork chops which turn out awesome as well.  Hghly recommend.

text:
DELICIOUS!  It's always a good thing when I can please my husband and 4 year old with one meal.  Based on reviews and our preferences, I made the following modifications:  substituted sour cream for half the mayo; doubled the "sauce";  added 1tbsp. minced garlic; added a few tablespoons of milk to make the sauce easier to spread and a bit more moist; sprinkled chicken with salt, pepper and garlic powder (didn't have garlic pepper).  Also, I cubed the chicken instead of using whole breasts since I find that easier to eat and serve.  I used regular canned artichoke hearts (drain and squeeze dry!) but might try marinated next time. I also might try adding in some diced roma tomato for color.

text:
I added a few things to the original recipe and it came out delish!  1/4 cup sour cream, two cloves minced garlic, 1/2 teaspoon lemon juice, 3/4 cup shredded mozzarella cheese, black ground pepper to taste and a sprinkle of breadcrumbs on top.. broil for a minute or two to brown, after chicken is finished baking.  I served the artichoke chicken with linguine and steamed vegetables.

text:
great start for a recipe. We took this and ran with it, added sauteed shiitake mushroom and spinach with fresh garlic, marinated artichoke hearts, kalamata olives and feta cheese. We used just enough mayo to moisten the mixture, but will definitely try the sour cream for a fuller creamy taste. We also pan seared the chicken coated in flour to seal in the moisture, sprinkled with paprika and cooked for 25 minutes. Amazing.

text:
Just finished eating this and had to sit down and say how delicious this recipe turned out! I added 1 minced shallot, some sliced, fresh mushrooms, and even a few sliced black olives that I wanted to use up, all around and over the chicken. I added salt-free chicken seasonings and a quick dash of sage to the mayo/cheese mixture, and for the cheese, I used half parmesan and half romano. The breasts I cooked were fairly thick, so it took about 40-45 minutes. (the last 3-4 minutes I broiled the dish to make the topping a nice golden brown) The end result was so good, my boyfriend asked for it again as soon as possible...a rarity! Thanks so much for this wonderful recipe. :)

text:
I got this from the Recipe of the Day yesterday and made it for dinner the same night.  It was really good!!!  I did change some things though.  I used 1/2 Mayo and 1/2 Sourcream, just adds some oomph!! And also used Italian Shredded Cheese which is a mixture and also Asiago Cheese, yummm.  Also chopped up the artichokes after draining. I cooked it for an hour and then took the top off and cooked it for another 20 minutes to brown the tops.  All in all, I didn't know what to make for dinner last night and this helped me along my way.  Hubby LOVED it and I will make it again!!!

text:
Easy and very tasty! I used organic mayo, frozen artichoke hearts (boiled before using), and grana padano in place of parmesan (a less expensive alternative here in Italy), mixed in garlic powder and black pepper since I don't have garlic pepper. I also decided to add a small can of sliced black olives, which I have to say was what did it for me. YUM. Served with cous cous and mixed veggies on the side. Not the healthiest dish available, but very flavorful. I can't wait to eat the leftovers...Thank you!

text:
I had mixed feeling on this. First off its easy and pie to make, very simple and I love that. I used half mayo / half reduced fat sour cream because I don't like mayo...to heavy and fatty for me. I kind of wished I would have used miracle whip but I was scared to deviate from the recipe too much but the mayo was very heavy, veryyyyyy heavy even with only half. My boyfriend who loves heavier eating even said it was a bit much. But it was GOOD. We did both devour it, the heaviness kinda hits you after though. I also used frozen artichoke hearts, which was yummy. I would make this again but I would do a bit differently, it was wayyy to bland so I would season the chicken first and do 80 / 20 sour cream and mayo. A keeper, but needed doctoring for us...

city:

country:
None
text:
I love this!! I can't make enough of it. I serve it with wheat pasta! Yum!

Updated 2010 Review:
Ok time is important, so I used a large skillet to cook my chicken, then I put 1 cup Parm, 1 Cup Mayo and 1 Cup Cream, Then add in Artichoke, I double it. For my own flavor... I add a can of mushrooms, a can of corn drained, and 1 Tbsp of Lemon Pepper with 1 Tbsp of Garlic Pepper and 1 Tbsp of Lemon juice. I don't fully drain the artichoke. For more color, I add shredded carrots about 1/2 cup. Minus Chicken for Vegatarians! Serve with pasta and bread.

2008 review:
My slight differences... I cubed up my chicken breasts (they were frozen, so I thawed them in the micro and then cubed them raw). Other feedback mentioned a lot of liquid so I used about 2 tsp of soya granules (equivalent to bread crumbs). I also used about 3-4 tsp of garlic pepper and then 1-2 tsp of lemon pepper and maybe a 1-2 tsp more of parmesan. I used half mayo and half sour cream and even extra sour cream. I think – since my oven is gas and does NOT have a temp gauge – I cooked mine hotter and longer than the recipe. Also, I did squeeze the artichoke of its excess liquid. Enjoy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is absolutely fantastic! I've made it a few times now and everyone that has eaten it has asked me for the recipe.

Now, being that I've made it quite a few times, I've come to add my own personal touches.

*1/2 mayonnaise and 1/2 sour cream (like most users have suggested, this really cuts down on the greasy feel)
*A few cloves of garlic, peeled and chopped
*A small, drained, and chopped can of sliced mushrooms
*A handful of pistachios, chopped (these add a little bit of crunch which is wonderful)
*A few cracker crumbs on top (I use honey wheat crackers; this also gives a crunch on top)

Overall, it is a wonderful recipe, revisions or not!

text:
This was really good. My husband and I liked it a lot. My kids, not so much. But then they are very picky and their idea of gourmet is homemade chicken nuggets.That said, I did tweek this recipe a little bit. I added half a jar of capers cause capers and artichokes just go so well together. I also added fresh chopped garlic and used less mayo. About 1/2 cup rather than 3/4 cup. Very good. I served with veg fettucine pasta with a light tomato basil sauce, and bruscetta and a salad. Opened a bottle of red wine and yumo! Delicious meal. I plan to make this for company next time. Definitely a meal to impress your guests!

country:
None
text:
This recipe is a good one, with only a few modifications. I seasoned the chicken breasts with garlic powder and pepper, then browned them in olive oil and butter. For the topping I used 1/2c ea. of mayo and sour cream. I also used diced garlic from the jar, and fresh black pepper. I used the same 3/4c parmasean cheese called for. I served the chicken over some spinach rice I made. The rice was just boiled with chicken broth. To the broth I added pepper, garlic power, and dried onion. When the rice absorbed the liquid. I tossed in fresh baby spinach and a little parmesean cheese and butter. The heavy artichoke chicken went great over the light simple spinach rice. I will make this again for sure!

text:
Another delicious dish from AllRecipes! Like many of the others...did half reduced fat sour cream, half light mayo. Also used marinated artichoke hearths and drained and squeezed out extra water. The recipe calls for 15oz can, the biggest can I could find of the marinated hearts was 12oz...didn't seem to make a difference, seemed plenty. Also topped with seasoned bread crumbs. My advice is you don't need much - I think when you sprinkle too much on top, it doesn't quite brown like I had hoped for. Sprayed spray butter on top to enable it to brown and it seemed to do the trick. 

My husband was in heaven...licked his plate clean. Served with seasoned green beans and parmesan cous cous. Delicious!

text:
This Artichoke Chicken dish was unbelievable! I doubled it and served it to guests last night. It was a big hit. I could not wait to eat the leftovers today. I followed previous reviewers' advice about not using just mayo. I used 1/2 Dukes light mayo and 1/2 low fat sour cream. I also flattened the chicken breasts just a little bit b/c they were real thick at one end. Also, I really squeezed out the artichoke juice as suggested. I had to cook the dish longer than 30 minutes to get the chicken done (checking with a thermometer), probably 40 minutes. It may have been because I had two pans in the oven. Awesome recipe! Thanks for sharing. I'm emailing this link to friends right now.

text:
This is decent.  I'm not sure I'm thrilled with the flavors completely, but I do like artichoke and I do like the tang.  Bf liked this a bit more than I did, I think.  It's quite easy and is something you can make up the night before (which is exactly what I did--bf just heated it up for dinner).  I chopped the artichokes in the food processor, which made it even more easy--just pulse a few times to get the right chopping consistency.  I think I pulsed a few more times than is ideal.  I used half greek yogurt and half mayo since I can't stomach that much mayo, and it worked out fine.  There was liquid in the bottom of my pan as another reviewer noticed--it's easily drained out.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This was really good.  I did make some changes that is why I have a 4 star review.  This is a great base recipe.    The changes I made are as follows.  I added 1/2 cup of fresh chopped spinach, I used just 1/4 cup of Mayonnaise (helmans light) and the rest light sour cream.  I added salt and black pepper and garlic powder to the mixture (just to taste not sure on the amounts).  I also added two tablespoons of panko bread crumbs for texture to the mixture.  I also seasoned my chicken with salt and pepper before adding topping.  After adding topping on chicken I sprinkled panko bread crumbs on top of each breast to add a little crunchiness to the topping.  Loved it!!!

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:
2009-03-06T09:30:51.953
helpfulCount:
3
userID:
3277381
Display Name:
Kate
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
49
favoritesCount:
79
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/137213.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading reviews, I used 1/2 mayo, 1/2 sour cream.  I also finely chopped onion and added that and some crushed garlic to the mix.  Another reviewer suggested breading the chicken first, so I tried that as well.  I pounded my chicken breasts flat, dredged in a flour, salt, pepper mixture, then dipped in a beaten egg, followed by a panko bread crumb, grated Parmesan mixture.  I allowed the breading to sit on the chicken for about 20 minutes in the fridge before I fried in 2 T. of olive oil on the stove top until crispy.  Then I topped with the artichoke mixture, and a bit more grated Parmesan and baked at 350 degrees for 25 minutes. Yum!

text:
This was excellent with many modifications!  I had some leftover grilled portabello mushrooms from this website and diced them up added to the very well drained marinated 7.5 container of artichokes.  I,too, used half of sour cream and half of olive oil infused mayonnaise.  I also added 2 fat  cloves of garlic.  No added salt or garlic powder, I figured the parmesan cheese would add plenty of salt.  Next time I would probably use real grated parm, I didn't have any on hand,just the shake on type.  Other than that, I cooked at 30 minutes, turned off and let it bake in the juices.  Delicious, easy, served with butter herbed rice, this is FANTASTIC!  Not asthetically pretty, but no worries, it smells delicious while cooking, tastes even better, and super easy clean up!

This was delicious. I made it as-is except for seasoning the chicken with S&P and garlic powder before-hand. The 2nd time I made it I added some chopped spinach to the mixture and that was really good as well.  The only thing I highly recommend doing is baking it for 20min,checking it, then baking it more if needed. The 1st time I made it I baked it for exactly 30 min and the chicken was overdone!  The next time I found 20min or so to be perfect.  This was a great alternative to the same ol' chicken, thanks!

text:
Gave this a three star only because of it lacking in flavour and had to do changes in it This was a good basic recipe to start. Seeing the reviews and noticing that it lacked flavour, I mixed can cream of mushroom soup and a touch of milk with the halved mayo and added the other half sour cream, sprinkled the top with grated marbled cheese and parmesian then topped with broken garlic seasoned croutons. Did add garlic and seasoning salt to the sauce. Also added sauteed onions over the chicken before adding the sauce. It was delicious this way. I don't really like artichokes so the next time I've decided to use cauliflower and broccoli or frozen mixed veggies to simplify it. Served it over rice because the sauce really goes well with it. Yumm. (I actually got the idea from a recipe my sister in law gave me to make pheasant devine.)

text:
This recipe was really really good. I love Artichoke dip so I thought I would give this a try. I used half Miracle Whip and half light sour cream mixed with the parmesan cheese. I also added 1.5 tsp minced garlic with a sprinkle or salt & pepper. Even though I did squeeze out my artichokes I did still have a clear liquid in the baking pan. It was easy enough to just drain the pan a few times while the chicken was cooking. I had to adjust the oven once and ended up cooking the chicken on 170 forced-fan oven for 40 mins in total. The top browned nicely and overall I thought the recipe was a great find. We had the chicken with a summer salad topped with craisins, slivered almonds, grated light tasty cheese and a light salad dressing. I also served fresh garlic bread and it was a great meal. Thanks again for the recipe.

text:
Definitely not a home run for me.  The artichoke topping was almost separate from the chicken as they really don't combine to make anything.  My oldest scraped the topping off and ate it instead of eating the chicken at all.  This recipe definitely was not worth the calories and isn't something I'll make as it is again.  I know that sounds so brutal, but if I'm going to splurge with this type of caloric and fat content, I want it to be as decadent as the calories and fat say it should be.  I might try it again but would perhaps go with chicken tenders or maybe even bake it as a caserole with cubed chicken so they don't seem like two separate components (you had chicken and then you had topping, but they weren't one dish together).  I might also be tempted to stir in some cream of celery soup, cream cheese or something to make it creamier. I'm sorry that this wasn't a home run for us, but it just didn't live up to our expectations.  We love artichokes and love artichoke dip too so we were hopeful that this would be a great answer for our artichoke cravings.

text:
This was good but not great.  Next time, I will make some changes.  I will pound out the chicken and cook it in a skillet with some olive oil to brown.  I think this will really improve the flavor! Lastly, I would place the artichoke mixture over the chicken and put it under the broiler until brown and bubbly.  Oh yes, and I would use more parmesan cheese.  I couldn't really even taste the parmesan like I had hoped and I used a really good quality parmesan.  By the way, I wouldn't use canned parmesan for this recipe. By making these changes, I think this dish would be really tasty!

Never in my life have I had baked chicken turn out so moist and tender.  Never.  When I told DH we were having Parmesan Couscous and Artichoke Chicken for dinner, he make strange gagging sounds and tried to convince me he had a prior engagement with his dentist and couldn't make it home in time for supper.  After much rolling of eyes and literally holding his nose like a 6 year old while trying to get him to take the first bite (I mean really - it's not a pretty dish straight out of the oven), he finally broke down ... and ended up having three plates.  I did use a marinated artichokes, a combo of mayo & sour cream and sprinkled the top with bread crumbs for the last 10 minutes of cooking to brown it up some.  Oh - and now I understand what others meant when talking about water forming on the bottom of the pan - but it was no big deal and I simply drained it off.  Great great recipe - thank you so much for sharing.  UPDATE:   See http://allrecipes.com/customrecipe/64354331/artichoke-chicken/detail.aspx (she added spinach & mushrooms ... sounds good)

text:
**EDIT**  I have made this several times and tonight got in a hurry and forgot to substitute half of the mayo with the sour cream. Ended up with a bunch of liquid in the pan and not near as good.  So the extra liquid people are experiencing is from the mayo! **EDIT**

Wow, this was great!  I forgot how much I love artichokes.  Definitely salt and pepper the chicken.  Also I substituted over half of the mayo with sour cream per the reviews, used light mayo (could possibly get rid of the mayo all together??), marinated artichokes (squeezed them out a bit before chopping,)and my dish turned out perfect... not too watery or greasy in any way!  I would say if you don't like artichokes you won't like this.  I loved it!

Just made this tonight for husband and myself.  I had to make a few substitutions based on what we had on hand. I did not realize that the artichokes we had were in water and not in a marinade. I added a few splashes of red wine vinegar (what I had) and could not find garlic pepper, so added a few cloves of chopped garlic.  Also, I substituted sour cream for most of mayonnaise, since we don't like mayo so much. Still, with these changes, hubby loved chicken. Oh, I also browned the chicken first in a little olive oil since we prefer browned chicken.  This is a very flavorful dish and I will make again since hubby is a artichoke fanatic!  Thanks so much for this recipe. It is truly delicious.

I made this when my friend and her 2 1/2 year old son came over for dinner. Big hit. Easy and tasty. Served with salad and bread. I actually mixed up the topping the night before and just put it together and stuck it in the oven when I got home from work. I didn't have garlic pepper and used 1/2 tsp minced garlic and some white pepper instead. I used all mayo and thought it tasted great. It was kind of watery as another reviewer said, but I used a slotted spatula and it was fine. If you are curious about what it tastes like, it's like artichoke dip on chicken. And you can't go wrong with either of those!

text:
This was really good after making a few changes.  First, because my breasts were really large, I sprinkled them with garlic salt and pepper and quickly browned them in EVOO.  For the mixture, I used canned artichoke (drained & chopped), fresh shredded parmesan, only 2/3 cup light mayo, and a little oregano and parsley. I put that mixture over the chicken and topped that off with Italian seasoned bread crumbs.  I then baked it for 35 minutes and then switched it to broil for the last 5 to brown the topping.  So good!  I served it with buttered parsley egg noodles and sauted fresh spinach with pressed garlic in EVOO.  I will be making this one again.  I might try half sour cream/mayo as suggested by others, but after the changes I already made, that might not make it any better.

Absolutely delish!  I took the advice of a few of the other reviewers & used equal portions of mayonnaise and sour cream to make up the 3/4 c. instead of just mayonnaise. text:
I gave the recipe 5 stars for being delicious and super easy. I did make a few modifications because I'm trying to lose weight. Instead of 3/4 cup of mayo I used 1/2 cup of low fat sour cream and 1/4 cup of fat free mayo. The artichokes I used were marinated, simply because that is what I had on hand. I seasoned the chicken with salt and freshly ground black pepper. I added 2 cloves of fresh garlic and a splash of white wine to the artichoke mixture. Some italian seasoned Panko bread crumbs would be really good on top, but I didn't try it because of the added calories. Thanks so much for such a simple and tasty recipes!

text:
Delicious, melt in your mouth chicken.  I give this 5 stars after some minor adjustments.  The first time I made this recipe I followed everything exactly as it was written. It turned out good, but was a little greasy. I think this was the mayo, so when I made it for the 2nd time last night I substituted half the mayo with light sour cream.  I also added a couple cloves of crushed garlic and some frozen, chopped spinach (thawed and drained), and increased the garlic pepper to 3/4 of a teaspoon.  Wow! I will definitely be adding this recipe to my regular rotation. My 15 year old son LOVED it, spinach, artichokes and all.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe a half dozen times already since January and each time it has gotten better and better with little tweaks. I use a can of marinated artichoke hearts, chopped fine, 1/2 a red onion diced,2 pressed cloves of garlic, salt and pepper and sour cream and mayo. I found that 2 parts sour cream to one part mayo ratio makes it creamy and not oily but still adds that rich flavor. Ive used both chicken tenders as well as breasts and prefer the tenders. I coat the chicken in the mixture and set in the pan, then spread the rest of the mixture over the chicken. I've also sprinkled the parm or mozz cheese is I was out of parm over the top about 5 minutes before it was done.  It has come out great everytime!!

How does something that easy taste that good?  I followed other reviewers' advice and used 1/2 mayonnaise and 1/2 low fat sour cream. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4264564.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW!  This is incredibly easy and incredibly delicious! I had 5 chicken breasts and sliced them into strips before cooking for easier serving and faster cooking. I also increased the topping ingredients some to accomodate the extra chicken.  To lighten this up some, I used 1 cup Reduced Fat Parmesan, and a ratio of 1/4 cup mayo to 3/4 cup Light Sour Cream for the mayo (thanks to suggestions from other reviewers!).  I had no garlic pepper, so I sprinkled garlic powder and a little fresh cracked pepper on the chicken and in the topping.  I also added some minced onion to the topping.  I added NO additional salt; this was plenty salty from the artichokes, parmesan, etc.  I sprinkled a little 2% shredded 4-cheese blend on the top for the last 15 minutes.   Total cooking time was about 40 minutes and the chicken was perfectly cooked and very juicy.  Rave reviews from my 3.5 yr old and my parents, and neither my father or my child is a fan of artichokes!  I will definitely make this regularly!

text:
I was not thrilled with this.  I thought I would be after reading reviews and I love artichokes.  My husband did say it was delicious, but I was disappointed.  I guess I thought the topping would melt down some and it didn't.  It was very thick on the chicken.  I pounded the chicken as other reviewers suggested, so the chicken was on the thin side and the topping overwhelmed it.  It was like taking a big bite of sour cream and mayo (I did do 1/2 sour cream and half mayo as other reviewers suggested).  I scraped half of it off my chicken and spread the rest really thin and then it was better, but I still ended up leaving half of it uneaten and was not impressed.  It did look and smell great as it came out of the oven and I thought I had a new dish for when company came over, but after eating it I've decided I won't be making this again.  Maybe if it was made more like a spinach artichoke dip like other reviewers suggested....

text:
My husband was skeptical, but ended up loving this! Because of earlier reviewers, I used mixed Miracle Whip and sour cream, and threw in some crumbled feta I had in the fridge.  I used canned artichokes, and chopped them on paper towel, but next time I'll squeeze the water out better, although it wasn’t too bad.  Worried about blandness, I put in some basil paste, a bit of asiago/parmesan/olive oil tapenade I had in the fridge, and topped the mixture-covered chicken with a bit of Parmesana Reggiano I had leftover from grating.  I used a pinch of garlic powder and fresh cracked black pepper, no salt because of the salty cheeses.  I served it with steamed asparagus topped with a lemon-dill sauce.  Very nice flavour, and 30 minutes at 350 in my convection oven was perfect.

Delicious!  I think I cooked mine a little too long, as it got a little dry, but it got rave reviews from everyone there, including my picky husband.  I put it on a bed of spinach (which unfortunately cooked down to just about nothing), put sauted onions on top, then the dressing, then some bacon.  It was delicious!  I served it with tri-color rotini and a salad.  Fantastic!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/239734.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was an excellent recipe! I used a can of artichokes from Trader Joe's and used Best Food's Mayo.  I did squeeze out excess juices from the artichokes.  I also used lots of garlic powder and black pepper in the mixture.  I sliced up 2 small italian squash into circles and lined a glass casserole dish.  I chopped up 1 more squash into small squares and sprinkled them on top of the mayo mixture after I layered it on the chicken.  I increased the cooking time by an extra 10 minutes, then turned off the oven, and let it sit for another 15 minutes to allow the squash to brown.  Once it was done, I sprinkled crushed red pepper on top for color.  It was beautiful, tasty and absolutely easy to make.  I would recommend this for everyone.  After searching high and low for the perfect side dish to go with recipe, I decided on a green salad made with romaine hearts, tomatoes and topped with dressing.  Very filling and yummy!

text:
I adored this recipe! Like others recommended, I used half fat-free mayo and half lite sour cream, added a couple shakes kosher salt.I also used fresh garlic (2 cloves, I love garlic) and I think that it makes the mixture.Oh! And I squeezed the artichokes by hand,I didn't want the dish to be watery. I seasoned the chicken breasts with adobo (dry caribbean/puertorrican seasoning),sliced them in half and browned them in a little olive oil.I put breadcrumbs and parmesan cheese on top. The smell was wonderful! I baked it for 40 minutes and broiled it for 2-3 minutes.Next time, I may add spinach!

text:
So quick & easy to prep, after I put it in the oven I went to re-read the recipe twice more to make sure everything was actually done! FH and I LOVED this! He had seconds. I used marinated artichoke hearts (well drained), half mayo & half sour cream, 5 cloves of fresh garlic (chopped). Dashed a small bit of cajun seasoning onto the chicken breasts before adding artichoke mixture on top. Next time will try adding 1 tbsp non-pariel capers to mix. Very flavorful. Baked in a 9x13 baking pan at 375 for 25 mins. Served with white rice but will add a salad next time or even make bruschetta. Definitely a keeper! I can see it would be a wonderful mix for dip, too. Thanks for the recipe.

This was fabulous! I used 1/2 cup of light mayo and 1/4 cup of fat free plain yogurt. I don't have any "garlic pepper", so I used a pinch of garlic powder and a dash of lemon pepper. I topped the casserole with a sprinkling of buttered breadcrumbs. I also reduced the heat to 350 and added about 8 minutes to the baking time. I could smell the yummy aroma almost immediately, and thought maybe it was cooking too hot. The whole family thought this was delicious, even the kids who at first said they'd never eat artichokes!

text:
I really enjoyed making this dish. I had the stuff I needed already, and didn't have to run out for anything... I did do some substituting, though... I did as some other reviewers said about the 1/2 cup of mayo and the 1/4 cup sour cream. For the garlic pepper, I used 5 cloves of minced garlic and lots of fresh ground pepper. I rinsed the artichokes to remove some of the oil. I did have some shredded parmesan cheese leftover, so I sprinkled it on top before baking. I served it with buttered egg noodles and honey wheat rolls. I bet it would go good with white or brown rice as well. Thanks so much for this quick and easy delicious recipe I can add to my list!

text:
Delicious & low carb, but a little greasy... I've made this several times - the last time was the best. Here are a couple of tips: use half sour cream & half mayo, the last 10 minutes turn the oven up to 400-450 to brown the top and drain off some of the juices after pulling it out of the oven. I also added 3 cloves of garlic, sliced water chestnuts, 1 tbs djion for added zip, 1/2 a red onion finely chopped and a little more cheese.  My parents can't get enough of this one. Presto a greasy, flavorful masterpiece!

text:
SUPER good! I cut up the chicken into slices when I made it, but next time I will cut up the pieces even smaller (bite size) to make serving easier. The "sauce" was soooo good. I think I will double that next time. I added fresh mushrooms to it and ended up with quite a bit of water in the dish after cooking. I don't know if it came from the mushrooms or the artichokes, so next time I will sautee the mushrooms first. Important to squeeze out as much excess liquid from the artichokes as you can. Really easy recipe & really really good! Will make over & over.

text:
This was pretty good...I used fat-free mayo and marinated artichoke hearts because it was all that i had.  The fat-free mayo turned out fine, but i didn't really like the marinated artichokes...too sour in this dish!!  So next time I will definitley try the water packed ones.  I also may try adding some spinach to the topping (I love spinach and artichoke dip, so why not?)...and maybe some fresh tomatoes at the end for color.  I used fresh garlic, and then added some garlic powder at the end when there wasn't enough of a garlic flavor.  I also scaled this dish down to one chicken breast (it was all that I had and I was the only one eating), but doubled the topping and served it over pasta.  This was definitley the way to go!!  I may make this again

Very good recipe, especially if you love, like we do, the infamous Artichoke Dip. I used a large can and a small jar of artichokes, which I whirled in the food processor with only about two heaping tablespoons of the mayo. I also added garlic and onion powders, black pepper, a squeeze of lemon juice and extra parm on top which I broiled for a minute or two once the dish was out of the oven. My kids had been bugging me to make the dip, so this was the perfect dinner solution. Thanks so much Ardrury!!

text:
Based on some excellent reviewers suggestions, I made some minor modifications.  First, used boneless, skinless thighs because I had them.  Used light Kraft mayo and substituted fat-free sour cream for half the mayo.  Also sauteed a shallot and two cloves of minced garlic to add to mayo/sour cream mixture.  I baked this at 375 degrees for 45 minutes and it was not quite done.  I recommend adding another 5 minutes.  Overall, the taste was very nice and I would make again.

userID:
9206506
Display Name:
Sandra
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was wonderful.  I used 3 chicken breasts, split.  My husband browned them with salt and pepper in oil.  I used 2   12 3/4 oz artichoke hearts (small) in water as we do not like the marinated ones,(too much oil, but love artichoke.)) To the mixture, I added the chopped artichoke hearts, 3/4 cup of grated Parmesan, 1/3 cup shredded pepper jack,  1/2 cup mayo, 1/4 cup light sour cream,  3 chopped
Green onion and 4-5 chopped spinach leaves. 
After we topped the chicken breasts with the artichoke mixture, I sprinkled the chicken breasts with garlic bread crumbs and then some paprika.  We baked for 45 mins at 375. Wowza!!  We loved the flavor.  I served this with cilantro lime rice- as the chicken is  rich in flavor, I wanted something lighter as a side.  It was wonderful!!

text:
I've made the topping as a dip many times, only with a few teaspoons of fresh squeezed lemon juice in the mix.  So, when I made this recipe, I did the same.  I used the entire topping amount on only two boneless, skinless breasts.  I was nervous about the 375 for 30 minutes being enough, so I put three long, vertical slices deep in each breast before topping them.  My husband showed me how he was able to cut through the breast (big, too) with only his fork!  He asked for this again and to NOT change a thing.  I served with chicken stock-cooked white rice and lemon roasted cauliflower.  Now the husband wants to have this topping on a good piece of fish.  Stay tuned.

text:
Excellent dish, and so easy.  I used a half cup of mayo and a half cup of sour cream--a little more than the recipe calls for because I also added a large half bag of thawed frozen spinach--and I subbed out the mozzarella for mild cheddar and added red pepper flakes.  I only used two large chicken breasts and cut them into cubes rather than leave them whole, to make it more of a casserole dish, and did not brown them first, I don't think this step is necessary.  It did take longer to cook than what the recipe states, about 45 minutes.   Delicious!

So I decided to do the half mayo, half sour cream, then I added cream cheese too. I also omitted the garlic spice and added chopped garlic, plus some fresh spinach. I guess I was craving spinach artichoke dip.  After I mixed everything up, I noticed some ritz crackers near me and dipped them in the mix, boy was it delicious. The hubby and daughter started eating it with the crackers too, and I had to stop them to remind them this was for the chicken. I baked the chicken for about 35 mins and broiled it for 2 mins. Chicken tasted somewhat sour, think I'll try marinated artichokes next time. I would rate this a 3.5 but since I altered it, I'll give it a 5. Was a little heavy and I preferred it as a dip.

I have made this twice.  The first time made by the original recipe and even though I liked it my husband did not stating it was very bland and greasy.   A couple weeks later I decided to make it again using reviewers reccomendation of marinated artichokes and half sour cream with the mayonnaise.   It was far superior with the slight changes.  My husband raved about and did not realize it was even the same dish I had previously made.  I am always looking for new recipes to serve guests and family and I  plan to serve this at my next dinner party.

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-03-19T13:32:12.43
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
9147600
Display Name:
jnnpppnk
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
54
favoritesCount:
325
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/819833.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Use 1/2 sour cream & 1/2 Miracle Whip instead of mayo. Marinated artichokes, drained, squeezed free of liquid and chopped  fine adds incredible flavour. Slice chicken into strips. Use 1.5 tsp. minced garlic plus salt & pepper to taste vs garlic pepper. Sprinkle top with cayenne or paprika before baking. VARIATION: Incorporate 10-15 oz. thawed spinach and 1 c sautéed portobellos into the dish. And 4-6 slices of crumbled bacon added to the artichoke mix is a Wowie! OR THIS from another reviewer:  FANTASTIC! Caramelize 1/2 onion in 3 tbsps of olive oil & a 1/4 tsp. of red pepper flakes. Remove  the onion and sauté a 1/2 pound of sliced/halved mushrooms with 3 cloves of minced garlic.. Butter a shallow glass baking dish. Layer the bottom of the dish with a bag of pre washed baby spinach. Place breasts on top of the layer of spinach and top each breast with caramelized onions and mushrooms. Drain two 12 oz. jars of marinated artichokes reserving a 1/4 cup of the marinade. Drizzle the reserved marinade over the spinach, breasts, caramelized onions and mushrooms. Cover each breast with the recipe mixture of mayo, parmesan cheese, marinated artichokes and garlic pepper. Lastly, VERY LIGHTLY sprinkle cayenne pepper over the dish. Bake at 375 for 50 minutes or until the topping is golden. OUT OF THIS WORLD!!!

text:
This was excellent.  It was flavorful and the perfect topping to dress up chicken.  I did modify per other reviews by using marinated artichokes and draining them well along with the combo of half mayo and half sour cream.  I added salt, pepper, dried minced garlic and red pepper flakes.  One other suggestion is to use chicken tenders or halve the chicken breasts because the chicken took a bit longer to cook and I was worried the artichoke topping would dry out.  Overall I will definitely be making this again.

text:
I think this recipe needs a few tweaks, but it's a tasty and easy starting point. After reading a few reviews, I did replace half the mayo with sour cream, and I think it would have been too greasy if I hadn't. Mine came out kind of runny and soupy though, and after reading more reviews, I think next time I'll not only drain the artichokes, but pat them dry as much as possible too. I may also add more parmesan next time, as we REALLY like our parmesan cheese. The flavor of this was great, so I really want to try it again and make it perfect!

This is a definite repeat recipe. I used some seasoned salt on the breasts before putting on the topping. Make sure you squeeze as much water as you can out of the artichokes. I used a large clove of minced garlic and black pepper in place of the "garlic pepper." I used a big spoonful of sour cream and the rest mayo. I also added a small can of mushrooms. We all had seconds. I was able to cover 6 breast halves with the topping instead of just 4 and cooked for 45 minutes. The chicken was so moist and juicy.

text:
I followed Jim F's advice and sauteed onion and mushrooms in butter, a pinch of red pepper flake, and garlic, spinach on bottom followed by seared chicken breast, topped with onion/mushroom mix, marinated artichoke (which I chopped fine), then sprinkled with cooked and chopped bacon and then I topped with mayo/parm mix and some italian breadcrumbs.  The meat-eaters loved it (can't speak for myself as I am vegetarian) but my guests have very good taste.
Thank you for the recipe :)  This one is a keeper!

text:
This has become my go-to dish for luncheons for friends. I split the chicken breasts lengthwise, to make smaller servings possible, though everyone can have whatever they want (I double the sauce, for 8 servings). I use half real mayo and half reduced fat sour cream. (I don't like "lite" mayo.) My husband also likes it, though I don't make it as often for the two of us, as it is rich. I'm serving it to a circle of friends this week, three of whom I had served it to last year, and requested it again!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a favorite in our house.  I, like others, only use half of the mayo.  For the other half, I use plain greek yogurt instead of sour cream.  VERY similar in flavor, but no fat! I also add a box of frozen chopped spinach (thawed), a second can of artichokes with a little of the juice, and some mozzarella cheese (I figure since the yogurt has no fat I can afford the extra cheese) to the mixture.  I also brown the chicken, seasoned with salt and pepper, first; it gives it more flavor and it just looks more appetizing. In addition to the cheese in the mixture, I top the whole dish with a little extra parm and mozz before baking. With these minor tweaks to the original recipie, it becomes a 5+ star dish :)

Yum! Just made this for dinner. I was going to replace 1/2 the mayo with sour cream like others had recommended, but my sour cream had gone sour so I just used the mayo, 1 tablespoon fresh minced garlic, parmesan cheese, & well chopped drained- dried marinated artichoke hearts. I browned the chicken breasts on both sides in a pan with a tbs of butter and salted and peppered to taste (my husband likes a little kick). This came out awesome. My husband said this is his favorite chicken recipe ever other than Cajun chicken, Highly recommend.

text:
It was ok. I used marinated artichoke hearts instead of canned and I think that made it better. I only eyeballed the amounts of everything--2 "thwacks" of mayo and 1 of sour cream, a tbsp of minced garlic (I love garlic), and a few dashes of pepper. I added one dash of cayenne but you couldn't taste it so I think I'll add more for next time.

I also think this would be better if you made the chicken separately and made the rest into a sauce. Next time I'll cook the chicken in a skillet and I'll mix up the mayo mixture in a pot, and maybe add some milk or something to make it more saucy to go with pasta. 
Overall I was happy with the flavor.

text:
Super easy and very tasty. Everyone loves it and it's a great dish to bring to someone who needs a meal! I tend to use less mayo (maybe 1/2 a cup) to keep the extra liquid down, and maybe a bit extra parmesan. I have substituted Greek yogurt for some or all of the mayo to keep calories down. Also, if the chicken is thick, I pound it to a uniform thickness so it cooks evenly and doesn't get dried out.

My boyfriend and I loved this! I did make my own changes though. 
I cooked up some rice and added that under the chicken breasts. 
I mixed a small amount of lemon juice into the rice
I butterflied two breasts to make four smaller ones. 
I used just a few marinated artichoke hearts (I have a huge jar from Costco). 
I added minced fresh garlic and fresh italian seasoning.
I used 1/2 mayo and 1/2 sour cream with just a bit more of the lemon juice.
Browned the top at the end and WALA! Heaven!

text:
This dish was very flavorful like the review before me had said. One thing that I found was that you have to really eat the chicken and artichoke mix together. It surprised me how great they went together. There were a few adds and changes i did with this recipe.  I added paprika and breadcrumbs, did half and half of sour cream and mayonnaise. 2 pinches of garlic pepper. I also squeezed the artichokes after draining. but there was still water in the dish.. which in all honesty it didn't matter. I would totally recommend this to anyone. thanks for the tips by the reviews before me:)

Read many reviews before making and thought since I benefitted from others' tips and hints re: this dish, I would ace the recipe.  Wrong-BLAND!  I used half mayo/half sour cream, Parmesan cheese and chopped Marinated Artichokes, drained well.  I added 1 clove finely minced garlic, and 1/2 small can of diced green chiles. It was okay, but BLAND AS HECK! we had one breast left over and today I added some Basil Pesto to the mayo topping and reheated.  Excellent!  I will try again using Pesto, that made it delish.

This was Delicious!  A few adjustments I made:  I used 1/2 the amount of marinated artichoke hearts, I Roasted some fresh garlic & used about 4-5 cloves of roasted garlic, pinch of lemon pepper, paprika,  that I mixed in with the Mayo, parmesan cheese mix.  I then sprinkled just a touch of seasoned bread crumbs on top of the chicken & mixture.  
I served it over garlic mashed potatoes, and sweet corn.  I will definitely make this again.   
Thanks for the recipe!

I made this last night for dinner - this was awesome I seasoned the chicken breast with salt/pepper slathered the top of the chicken with the artichoke/mayo mixture sprinkled with bread crumbs turned the breasts over and repeated on the other side - I baked mine for 40 min since the chicken breast were large - the flavors where great and the chicken was so moist - served over wild rice - thanks this is so so easy and a keeper in my house.

GM

This was good, but it didn’t wow me like I was hoping it would.  I used marinated artichokes squeezed of excess moisture in a paper towel, fresh pressed garlic and freshly ground pepper. I still had plenty of the artichoke mixture to spread on the chicken breasts covering them totally.  Sprinkled it with lightly buttered panko, hoping to help it crisp up, and that probably helped, but it still wasn’t as crispy as I would have liked.

Good as is, better with these changes:  ahead of time, fry 5 slices of thick sliced bacon, let cool and then crumble and add to the mixture.  Increase mayonnaise (or mayo/sour cream combo) to 1¼ cups.  Boil four potatoes for about 10 minutes, let cool and cut into cubes and place around the chicken before covering all with the mixture.

YUM! I've made this several times now! So tasty and so easy and quick to prepare! Great with asparagus and a salad, yummy!

I too loved this dish and did mince the artichoke hearts as I am not a fan of chunks of artichoke, plus I split the may with sour cream and added spinach to make it more of a "chicken spinach & artichoke dip" style. The chicken is so juicy when baked with the mayo and sour cream it is just to die for! Another idea is to slice the chicken into strips rather than leave it as halves to make it even more juicy when baked. MMmmm Mmmm good!

WOW!!! My husband is not a big eater nor is he a chicken lover but he does like artichokes and all he kept saying throughout dinner was how good it was. Not to mention my kids cleaned their plate which is also very rare. I don't think I have ever had chicken come out so moist,even looked beautiful and delicious when it came out of the oven. I cooked slightly longer due to large pieces of chicken breasts but did follow the recipe exactly and will be making often!

text:
I liked this.  I did as other commenters suggested and used 1/2 (fat free) sour cream and 1/2 (olive oil) mayo instead of all mayo.  I also used half feta cheese and half parmesan and added a can of very-well drained spinach.  It took about 45 minutes for the chicken to cook all the way through, but it was really good.  It tasted like having spinach and artichoke dip baked onto the chicken!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family loves this recipe.  I make it a little bit different than the original recipe.  First, I only use 2 large chicken breasts.  I pound them down until I can cut them into 4 equal pieces.  The I make the artichoke mixture with fresh parm. cheese.  It makes a big difference in the taste compared to store bought parm.  I have done both just depends on what I have in my fridge.  Then I let it bake for 25 minutes.  I take it out, cover the top with 1/4 c. original bread crumbs and 1/4 c. parm.  Then I bake it for another 10 minutes.  It has a wonderful crust on top.  Wonderful :)  My whole family eats this dish.  Even my picky eaters!

text:
This is wonderful!!  My husband who usually says everything is "good" or "OK" said it was "really good" I did add a couple of things as follows.  Didn't have any parn cheese so I used the ricotta cheese on hand, instead of 3/4 c mayo I used 1/2 c mayo and 1/2 sour cream.  Also added 1 t. worchestshire sauce, 1 t. lemon juice, 1 t. minced garlic, 1/2 t crushed red peppers, 1/2 t salt, 1/2 t pepper & a pinch of ginger.  I wanted a little pick but not hot.  It was perfect!  I serverd it with whole wheat penne pasta and sauted asparagus.  YUM!

text:
I made this for Sunday dinner and it turned out great.  My husand is an artichoke fan and loved it.  I did follow the recipe fairly close.  I followed others advice and added 1 1/2 tsp. minced garlic to the mayo mix. Also, I sprinkled the chicken with garlic powder and salt and pepper.  I also, did as another suggested and checked the chicken after 20 min. I used artichoke hearts packed in brine and squeezed the juice out really well. Use real shredded parmesan cheese not the kind you shake out of the can.  I used a meat thermometer to make sure it wasn't overdone. (At 145 degrees the juices were clear) That is the key!!! It was like something out of a restaurant!  I did only use a little over half of the mayo mix as it is quite rich and the chicken came out perfect!

5

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for an impromptu dinner party and it was so scrumptious my guests were scrambling to get the last morsels.
Changes I made: Reduced mayo by 1/2 and then added 1 part cream cheese and 1 part sour cream; I added 3 cloves minced garlic and about 1/2 c chopped spinach; I sauted the garlic, spinach, and artichoke hearts prior to baking; I used a 3-cheese blend of fresh parmesan, asiago, and romano cheeses.
Served on a bed of long grain brown rice cooked in chicken broth and with roasted broccoli, cauliflower, and red peppers.

This chicken is GREAT!!  Only changes I made were I halved the mayo and subbed sour cream, I used chicken breast tenders, and in half of the cheese mix, I added fresh spinach. I will definately make this recipe again! Thanks Amanda for submitting!!

text:
I am actually pleasantly surprised. Everyone ate it, everyone liked it - anything that isn't complained about is a five star in my book!! I took other's advise did the half mayo/sour cream route. Sauted my chopped up marinated artichokes, some mushrooms and roasted red peppers, thought this would take away the "watery" problem some talked about, it didn't, but the watery thing didn't matter. I also added chopped up cooked bacon, and lighty sprinkled the top of the chicken with steak seasoning. I also cut the parm down to 2/3 a cup because I was afraid it would taste too salty. It was not appealing at all as I put it on top of the chicken, and even tasting the mixture didn't seem too good. It smelled great cooking, and like I said, it was actually very good. Wont make it very often just because it is a rich meal, but it will be made again!! Thanks!!

We liked this recipe a lot. Not only because it was very easy to cook but because it was a very simple tasting dish. The picky boyfriend went back for seconds and asked me to save the leftovers! text:
Ok, I have tried this recipe twice, because of all the good ratings, because I love artichoke dip and I really wanted to like this dish because it looked fast and easy. Once, exactly as written and once, using the suggestions of others (ie: marinated artichokes, half sour cream half mayo, garlic).The way it's written is bland and the suggested way is not that good either. The marinated artichokes give the chicken a sour taste.  Plus, no matter how long you drain the artichokes you end up with the chicken swimming in liquid.  It also did not brown on top and just did not look appealing to the eye.  I would not make this dish again.

text:
I rated this a 4 star because of all the changes I made based on previous reviews. I put artichokes in food processer with several thick slices of onion, about 1 tsp of chopped garlic and processed.  I mixed 1/2 cup mayonnaise and 1/2 cup sour cream along with 3/4 cup parm. cheese and added the chopped mix.  I did not have marinated artichokes so I brushed a robust italian dressing on my chicken prior to adding the topping.  I also baked longer - 50 min.  The result was very good however next time I will used the marinated artichokes.  Will def. make again.

text:
Liked this original recipe but it was a bit tangy...so I took the advice of previous posters and switched to 1/2 mayo and 1/2 sour cream.  I also use marinated artichokes that I squeeze to get most of the juice out.  Then I add chopped roasted red peppers to the mix as well.  Just before the dish is finished I top it with shredded mozzarella and bake until it's browned.  Fabulous...my husband asks for it again within days!

I LOVE this recipe!  Since everyone in my house refuses to eat artichokes, I end up making a dish for myself when I get the urge, and then eat on it for a few meals. city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I'll definitely make this recipe again, I just tweaked a few things to suit my tastes.  I would definitely recommend marinated artichokes instead of plain canned ones.  When I just used canned ones I added 2 tsp. dried dill.  Also, spend the extra $1 and get the higher quality artichokes (instead of storebrand), otherwise you may get a few tough choke tips.  I drained the artichokes to solve the water problem and to make it a little more heart friendly I used 1/4 cup light mayo and 1/4 light yogurt.  I love artichoke dip and now I love artichoke chicken!

I also used marinated artichoke hearts, which I think caused the dish to be a little salty for us.  Next time I will try plain ones to see if it cuts down on the saltiness.

Display Name:
Christine

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this last night (with some changes) and hubby and I liked it a lot.  Chicken was very moist & the topping was delicious.  Picky 5-yr old & 2-yr old sons actually ate the artichokes while our adventurous-eating 6-yr old daughter scraped them off - go figure!  
To reduce baking time, I pounded the chicken breasts to make them thinner, and I put them in the oven for the 5-10 minutes it took me to assemble the topping, to give them a head start on cooking.  
To reduce the fat content, I used less than 1/2 cup of light mayo & about 1/4 cup of Parmesan plus lots of garlic powder, a generous squirt of fresh lemon juice, and some pepper.  We did not find the mayo taste overpowering, maybe because I used less & it allowed the artichoke flavor, enhanced by the lemon juice, to come through.  Also mixed some bread crumbs with a little olive oil and sprinkled that on top for a nice crust.  
Fast & easy to prepare on a worknight and will definitely go into our rotation.

text:
This was good but for my personal tastes, not the best.  A little too greasy tasting.  My husband loved it though, so I'll probably make it again.  I did substitute more than half the mayo with sour cream and used minced garlic and salt and pepper instead of garlic pepper.  I think next time I will substitute sour cream for all of the mayo and cut the amount in half - just use maybe 1/4 cup.  The marinated artichokes and cheese should carry enough flavor for the dish.  It took close to an hour to cook in my oven!  And my oven is not typically slow like that - I think it was due to the large amount of topping on the chicken breasts - be aware that this could take much longer to cook in your oven.  I would probably use less topping next time anyway.

country:
None
text:
This recipe is great! I made a few amendments to the original recipe. I substituted Delallo's marinated artichokes for ordinary artichokes. Also, to ensure that the dish wasn't "runny", I completely drained the artichokes and even squeezed the excess moisture out of each of the artichoke hearts. I also recommend adding a dash of white pepper and sprinkling some garlic salt into the dish. This dish took a bit longer than 30 minutes to cook...use a thermometer to check the temperature of the poultry after 30 minutes in a 375 degree oven. Enjoy!

text:
When I started making this meal, I was starving after a long day of running errands.  I put a little bit of the artichoke mixture in the microwave and did a dip with pita chips - wonderful!!  I did half mayo and sour cream as others suggested.  We were tired of chicken so I used cod (fish) filets instead.  Delicious!  I used half marinated artichoke hearts because it's what I had on hand.  I liked the taste of half marinated and half not. my family (4 teens, 3 adults) would have liked less Parmesan cheese in the artichoke mixture - too cheesy for them.  But other than that we will make this again.  I may even use it as a dip for the Holidays!!

text:
This was excellent, but because I didn't realize that I didn't have mayo until I was already going, I really changed it up.  I cut up 4 chicken breast and sauteed it with the garlic pepper in the olive oil, then mixed together the artichokes with 1 can cr. of chicken soup and 1 cup of sour cream and 3/4 c. parmesan cheese.  I sprayed my casserole dish and covered the bottom with egg noodles, then the chicken, then the artichoke mixture.  I topped it with mozzarella cheese and cooked at 375 for 30 minutes - turned out yummy!  I have mayo on my grocery list to try it the right way next, but just in case you did what I did, this recipe is still great!

Five stars does not do this justice. 
I used chicken tenders instead of breast. I also mashed the artichoke mixture with a potato masher until it was a paste and covered the entire chicken with the mixture. For a little extra flavor, I added sauted onions and mushrooms to the top of the paste five minutes before I took it out of the oven. Thank you Ardrury for the best chicken recipe ever!

text:
This is great!  It is quick and easy too!  I made a few alterations to the recipe.  I browned the chicken and chopped it up in small pieces as other reviewers suggested.  For the artichokes, I drained them and used a paper towel to squeeze out the excess liquid in the artichokes.  I couldn’t find garlic pepper at the store so I minced 1 fresh garlic clove and added some pepper.  I mixed it with the cheese and mayo, put it on top of the chicken and then I baked it.  My mother who doesn’t like artichokes even liked this!  She took a small bite and said,  “Oh, this is good!  It has a really good flavor.  Can I have some more?”  I couldn’t have said it better myself!

I thought this was pretty good, but my husband felt it was a little on the rich side.  Had I had some sour cream, that might have lightened it a bit.  I  did cut the mayo to 1/2 cup as suggested and used fresh pressed garlic and fresh shredded parmesan.  I baked it at 500 degrees for 15 minutes and it came out really moist!  I broiled it at the end to give it a little more color as well.  This is a quick and easy way to bake chicken that I use whenever I'm rushed for time (and with a 3 year old constantly tugging at me - that's all the time!!)  If I make this again, I'll try 1/4 cup sour cream and 1/4 mayo.

text:
I took this recipie, and made it a completely different dinner........I found that I didn't have enough chicken stir fry pieces to feed the whole family, so I took the artichokes and whisked them with the mayo in the food processor, and on the side I sauteed the chicken pieces in some olive oil until golden brown.  Then I put the artichoke mixture on top of pizza dough, topped with the chicken and mozz/parm cheese.  Very good, and a quick save for a dinner to feed all of us!

I will definately make it again with yogurt,  I also threw a little blue cheese in the second time I made it, that is a great touch too if you like that flavor

Love this dish! I did follow some wonderful recommendations in the reviews. One thing I did was pound and marinate the breasts for about 6-8 hours in Italian dressing. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I sautéed chopped onion and mushrooms, before adding it to the artichoke mix. Subbed half the mayo with sour cream. Pounded the chicken breasts flatter. (I can see why others have browned the chicken before cooking, it's very white under the spread.) In fact the final dish will look pale, so before the 30 minutes are up, put it under the broiler to improve color. Note to self: try adding spinach or at least serving on the side. 2ND Review: I added thawed (squeezed dry) spinach as a bottom layer, then chicken and artichoke mix.  The last ten minutes I sprinkled on bread crumbs, extra Parmesan and paprika. Final meal was delicious, hearty and colorful.  Win win.

Have made this multiple times- the entire family likes it; even those who don't like artichokes. We substitute plain yogurt for the mayo or use half plain yogurt/ half mayo with good results. country:
None
text:
We make this about once a month.  It's important to well drain the artichoke hearts if they are in olive oil.  Also, personal preference is that this is one of those meals that are best made, cooled, then reheated to eat to allow flavors to set up and reduce some of the "wateriness" of the dish when it's right out of the oven.  We also altered sprinkling additional garlic pepper over the top prior to be baking that adds a nice textural note.

text:
Family seemed to love this, all plates were licked clean! I used 6 chicken breasts (for 6 people) and just doubled the sauce for simplicity (to use 2 cans artichoke hearts). Pounded the chicken breasts and sprinkled with salt and pepper before putting in pan. (I didnt have garlic pepper so added garlic powder to sauce) I assumed it would need to bake longer since I basically doubled the recipe, but I think I baked a little too long... shouldve baked about 40-45 min. Served with orzo and sliced tomatoes (spinach wouldve been a nice addition as they did in the video). Will definitely make again! May try a jar of marinated artichoke hearts next time (and then leave out garlic powder?)

text:
Love this meal, but prefer it best with a few changes: I season the chicken breasts with garlic powder, salt and cracked pepper. To the artichoke mixture, I add in some fresh garlic, scant cayenne pepper, and pearl onions. 15 minutes into baking, I top it with a mixture of Panko, garlic powder, cracked pepper and a little melted butter (mix and sprinkle on top of and return to oven). This recipe is fantastic this way, and still very easy.

text:
OMG, This was phenomenal!!!!!!
My hubby loved this, and is in my rotation for sure.

For the cheese mixture, I did half mayo (cains) and half sour cream... with the Parmesan.  I bought a marinated jar of artichoke hearts.  Adds a lot of flavor to the sauce.

After mixing the cheese mixture well,  I added some capers, (about 2 TBLspoons, sautéed (1) small vidalia onion, and button mushrooms to the mixed cheese sauce. 

 Sprinkled the chicken breasts with some paprika.

I cooked it covered to keep it moist.

Served with a side salad and white rice.

Yum Yum!!!!!

text:
Made this last night and it's a keeper! Adjusted ingredients for two breasts. I cut my breasts in half lengthwise, used 1/ 4 cup each mayo and light sour cream, heaping 1/4 cup parm and 1/2 12 oz jar of marinated artichoke hearts, and didn't squeeze the juice out of them. Added garlic powder and shook some Montreal Steak seasoning and panko crumbs on top, too.  Baked about 35 minutes at 375. Served with jasmine rice and fresh green beans. Delicious! Thank you for a great recipe!
Review:
Rating:
4

Display Name:
Jennifer Kohn Murtha
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for Father's Day, as we had  a small crowd. Read every single review and thank you all, as it helped me to tweak this until I was happy. I put the artichokes on a paper towel and squeezed-perfect! So then...I used the mayo as written, but added a half can of cream of mushroom soup and a tablespoon of bottled ranch dressing,plus some water until it was the consistency I wanted. I added the parmesan, with the addition of shredded colby-pepper jack.  Then I added seasoned salt, dill, parsley and garlic powder to taste. I pre-cooked the chicken but not to brown, just  until done.  Once assembled, I sprinkled it with parmesan cheese and liberally with seasoned panko breadcrumbs. Baked it for forty two minutes, until golden brown  and served it with artisan rolls with fresh butter and a salad with ranch and dried cranberries and other goodies. It was just great! We ALL loved it and it has been requested again.

text:
This came out really good, although it would almost be better as a chicken casserole with the chicken cubed into small pieces so the flavor could mix into the chicken. With the artichoke topping on top, the chicken itself was a bit bland. That's the reason for 4 stars vs 5. But the topping was incredible!! I added mushrooms and only put in a tiny bit of mayo. I subbed the rest of the mayo with some sour cream and cottage cheese puréed into a smooth mixture. It really was delicious!

text:
A simple and delicious dish that can feed the family inexpensively. 
I used chicken quarters as they were on sale. I added chopped yellow onion which made the sauce that much better. I also used light mayo which kept the sauce from becoming greasy as some have said. If I'd had more time I would have deboned and marinated the chicken. Next time I plan to add mushrooms, green onion, dill and bake the chicken on a bed of wild rice or stuffing

userID:
8852606
Display Name:
tyree25

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe exactly as stated except the garlic pepper (I didn't have it) and I used 3 chicken breasts instead of 4. I used a pinch or garlic powder, pinch of pepper, and pinch of salt to replace the garlic pepper.  I used 3 organic skinless boneless chicken breasts. As far as flavor, the artichoke topping on the chicken is AWESOME. However, eaten as a whole, I wanted more salt on mine. Following the baking instructions, my chicken turned out rubbery and stringy. The only way to make it palatable for me was to shred it and mix it with rice. My 3 year old LOVED this, and she can be very picky. So, I consider it a good recipe. However, in the future I will either bake the chicken at 450 for 15-20 minutes alone and then add the topping and broil it for 5 minutes or so. Or, I will cook the chicken in a pan till almost done then pop it in the oven on broil with the artichoke topping.

This was so delicious and easy to make.  In my opinion, It does not need sour cream! I used Helman's mayo and I used marinated artichokes like others suggested which absolutely made a difference. I have been making this recipe for well over a year and it's about time I comment on it. My husband requests it constantly. The flavor of the artichokes is strong and so lovely.
