text:
I did this recipe with a twist. I added spinach, bacon, and cut how much mayo should be used. I also used mozzarella instead of parmesean. I used 2 tablespoons of mayo. After cooking the bacon, I chopped it up in bits and added it to the mixture of artichoke, spinach, and cheese. I also stuffed the chicken as well as put it on top. Finally, I used the bacon grease on the bottom of the baking pan that the chicken cooked in to give it some more flavor.

userID:

Display Name:
rob b
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a good dish, I've made it twice now. The first time I found it just a tad bland (even with sufficient spices). Here is how I spruced it up and really took it to the next level!

Use half mayo & half sour cream 

Use half Parmesan and half shredded mozzarella

Add chopped baby Bella mushrooms to the mixture.

Once the mixture is on top of the chicken add chopped sun dried tomatoes (the sweetness really complements the salty dish well).

For some kick I diced fresh Serrano peppers 

sprinkle some crispy bacon to add a little crunch.

A last sprinkle of Parmesan that will crisp up nice in the broiler after baking will give it a beautiful finish.

Toss some smoked paprika on top of it all for color and a bit more subtle flavor

I like to garnish the pan around the chicken with full Bella mushrooms and sun dried tomatoes 

Fin!
Review:

4

text:
Really simple and really delicious!  Not super healthy but there are easy substitutions you can make to make it more healthy.  10 mins prep 30-40 mins cook time - great for a weeknight quick meal that doesn't taste "quick."  Suggestions - 1) put a rack in the dish and bake the chicken on that, otherwise your chicken will be sitting in liquid by the end even if you squeeze out the artichokes.  I spooned out liquid about 2/3 way in then continued baking 2) i baked at a bit higher temp for 20-30 mins, then broiled for 2 mins to brown the top. 3)  I sprinkled some bread crumbs (panko) on to for some crunch.

text:
DELICIOUS!  Definitely a KEEPER!  I'll be making this often and it's definitely company-worthy.  

I used marinated artichokes, and added bacon as per another review.  Only had 1/4 cup of shaved Parmesan cheese on hand which concerned me, but it turned out not to be a problem.  Also, did not have garlic-pepper on hand - never even heard of it - so I added 1 tsp of garlic powder and 1/4 tsp of pepper.

I didn't tell my husband what I was making.  He took a bite and after a few chomps on his food, he  sat straight up and froze for a sec, then said, "ARTICHOKES!"  He was quite delighted and cleaned his plate.  =D

I served the chicken over a bed of buttered egg noodles with a side of steamed broccoli.  It was excellent!

text:
It hardly seems fair to rate and review a recipe that I have adapted so much, but! It is such a fantastic inspiration and starting point for a meal that has become a family favorite that I do hope you will try it as it is written or with your own special twists.
I followed Jim's advice and do a bed of caramelized onions and mushrooms on the bottom of the baking dish. I also substitute the mayo with Greek yogurt and 2 TBSP of extra virgin olive oil, add the juice from half a lemon, a whole bunch of crushed garlic cloves, and thyme to the sauce and bake as directed. I serve this lovely symphony over the top of fresh baby spinach.
TRY IT! It's a dish fit for company and kings!! Do Amanda's original or any of the multitude of other suggestions here. This is truly a spectacular dish.

Made it last evening for dinner.  Was absolutely delicious! But I love artichokes!  I knew I was going to like this as it has the same ingredients as a dip I make.  I used mayo just as it called for (do not use low fat when cooking with mayo).  I diced a little roasted red pepper to mix in for color. I will definitely be making this again and agree it would work well for company.  I served with Indian green beans.

country:
None
text:
I couldn't make this and not add garlic so I chopped up a bit of onion, garlic and peppers and added it into the mix. Instead of topping the chicken breasts I cut pockets into them and sort of stuffed the filling in. I used a bit of mayo but also a bit of natural Greek yogurt which I like to substitute when I can. I would only ever use the jarred artichokes for this.. for what you get in the end there is no reason to go through the hassles of cutting out the fresh hearts and the jarred ones add to the flavour anyways.

Very yummy and I'll definitely make it again.

Made the recipe as is.  Quite tasty!  I used marinated artichokes and squeezed as much liquid as I could get out of them (they hold quite a bit).  There was just a bit of liquid in the pan, which I discarded and served the chicken over a bed of rice.  I also sliced the breasts into strips so that they would cook quicker.  Would make this recipe again!

text:
Tastey! Super Easy! My tip, squeeze the water out of the artichokes otherwise the nice creamy sauce will become thin and watery. I used 2/4 cups  light mayo and 1/4 cups light sour cream as suggested in reviews,  but I know the recipe  with full mayo, would be just as good! I used the 3/4 cups bagged pre- shredded Parmesan cheese, mmmm.  I gave 5 stars for ease of making this recipe, someone with little skill and little time can make this and pull off a meal that will wow them.  Also 5 stars for  taste to recipe as written,   for the ease of making it, and the  few inexpensive easy to get type of  ingredients from any store. For such an easy recipe it is really good. No reason to buy frozen, or ready made meals, or buy from a drive through when you have this quick recipes like this on hand. I look for easy recipes as we do not dine out nearly as often,  and cook 99 percent of all meals at home. So if you are busy try this one. I added some red chilli peppers on mine for a little kick, and  a sprinkle of black freshly ground pepper. My husband loved it. I squeezed the water out if the artichokes to keep the water down in the cream sauce. I used dehydrated garlic and garlic power, and freshly ground pepper as that is what I have on hand. The only thing I added was some sautéed mushrooms because I love them in a creamy sauce with chicken,  and we don't often get to eat a creamy sauce like this one. I used chicken thighs cut up. Pretty much all the same as original ingredients, j

This was good.  Basically it was an artichoke dip on top of chicken.   I doubled it to feed my larger family, and didn't have enough artichokes, so I used a package of well-drained (cooked) spinach.   Yummo.  Also, to finish, I transferred the chicken to a new dish (to rid it of the liquid), and cooked for another 7 minutes.  Worked well.  Let it sit for a few minutes before serving.  That helps with any mushiness.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I added a few steps but it greatly added to the flavor.  I first sautéed the artichoke with a tablespoon of garlic and shallots with butter for about 30 seconds.  I also added roasted red and scallions.  I then put them in a mixing bowl and mixed with a little mayo, sour cream, Dijon mustard, and Feta cheese in addition to the Parmesan and garlic pepper in the recipe.  After topping the chicken I also sprinkled with panko bread crumbs.  I baked the chicken for 30 min., then turned on the broiler and finished under the broiler for 4 min. creating a toasted brown crunch over the juicy chicken.  

I know this is a lot of adaptation it came out great!  I highly recommend it.

This was great!  I used freshly grated parmesan cheese and freshly pressed garlic (3 cloves) in the mayo/artichoke mixture. text:
Very good recipe that was quick and easy for a weeknight dinner. Had to extend cooking time to about 35 minutes as it was still a bit pink at 25 minutes when I cut open one of the pieces. I added some cayenne pepper into the artichoke mixture to give it a kick and also some chopped green onions for  added color and flavor. If you've ever had the artichoke dip that is very popular, this is basically that on top of your cooked chicken breast. Served it with the Orzo and roasted vegetables recipe I found on here and it was a nice accompaniment to this entree.

Sprinkled top with little pepper.  Could add spinach to topping too.  ***served w/ roasted veges: broccoli, mushroom/portabella, yellow & red mini peppers

This was really good, and I didn't find it to be too rich as other reviewers commented. I did use marinated artichokes and used a bit more than the recipe called for. I also used a mix of low fat sour cream and mayo and it turned out great. Total bake time was 40 minutes with four large breasts. I will definitely make this dish again as it was a big hit with my family.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I loved how easy this was to make, and everyone enjoyed the flavor.  Kind of like artichoke dip with chicken.   I did, however, make two adjustment that did not work: I cubed the raw chicken, and I added fresh spinach to the bottom of the dish as another reviewer had. The problem was with the increased surface area of the chicken and likely the addition of the fresh spinach,  too much juice was released, so there was about 1/4 of watery mess in the bottom of the pan.  The spinach just looked unappetizing.  I would do this again, but I would precook the cubes, and I would add a package of frozen chopped spinach (thawed and squeezed dry) to the artichoke mayo mix.  This is a definite flavor feast if you like artichokes dip!

country:
None
text:
This was very good! I am not a big fan of chicken breast, as it always seems to be dry and bland no matter what I do. The chicken was very tender and there was a lot of flavor. I pounded the chicken a little bit and put salt and pepper on before putting the artichoke mixture on the top. I used 1/2 mayo and 1/2 plain greek yogurt (to save some fat and calories) and fresh, minced garlic and cracked pepper. I also sprinkled Italian bread crumbs on the top and put under the broiler for 5 minutes after baking. Definitely drain and pat dry the artichokes, otherwise you can get a lot of liquid after baking. I am going to try to carmelize some onions and add it to the mix next time. Thanks for sharing!

text:
Like others I made some changes: 1/2 c olive oil mayo, 1/2 fat free plain Greek yogurt instead of 3/4 mayo. 2/3 c Parmesan & 1/4 c feta instead of all Parm.  I added 3 cloves of minced garlic to mix and directly generously sprinkled the garlic pepper to chicken. I used the artichoke hearts in water.  I also sprinkled 1/4 teaspoon of cayenne pepper over the top & sprinkled paprika over the top to give it more zing.  Turned out FANTASTIC!!  I served over a bed of brown rice & baby spinach. Can't wait to make it again!

This was really good!  
The changes I made, based on reading reviews: 
-Use half mayo & half sour cream; 
-Add some of the artichoke marinade to the mix;
-Add a carton of chopped cremini mushrooms and half a container of french fried onions;
-Put a fresh bag of spinach on top of the chicken (cover w/ foil while cooking to steam the spinach)
Thanks for sharing! (& thanks everyone for commenting with your changes - it always helps!) :-)

text:
1st time cooking with Artichokes-It was excellent! I double checked the recipe before shopping only bought "plain" not marinated (which are less expensive)canned artichokes. I followed the recipe exactly and used Hellman's mayonaise (is there any other??) I had about 1/3 parm cheese that I grated and the remaining was from my cannister.  This took a little longer to cook as my trimmed breasts were large - I also drained out the extra clear liquid from the pan just before they were done cooking. My husband, who was apprehensive about the artichoke loved it! When it came out of the oven browned and bubbly - very nice! I used garlic powder and black pepper and no salt - parmesean cheese makes it salty enough.  The chicken was so tender and juicy - the sauce rich and full of flavor - light accompaniments are all that is needed with this entree!

text:
I did the half mayo/half sour cream mix.  The artichoke part tasted great, but it really didn't get through the chicken all that well.  I would like to try this again, but maybe some sort of presentation where you cut the breasts in half then butterfly them and stuff them, then panko bread... that would help with the texture issue (this is very loose and a little chewy) as well as the appearance (not very pretty to look at in this rendition -- I agree that some bread crumbs on top would be good.)  Definitely something to work with though, the artichoke/mayo/sour cream is a keeper.

Display Name:
Geo Teacher

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1612929.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This dish was so wonderful that my husband licked his plate!  Based on other reviews, I made the following changes.  1. Used 1.5 lbs of chicken tenders, seasoned with garlic pepper, browned in light virgin olive oil to add color and to make sure chicken was cooked thoroughly  2. added 1 lb of sliced mushrooms sauteed in light olive oil seasoned with garlic pepper and onion powder  3.  substituted 1 can reduced sodium cream of mushroom soup and 1 can of roasted garlic mushroom soup for mayo because I don't like mayo  4. used marinated artichoke hearts  5. added frozen, baby sweet peas.  I mixed shredded parmesan cheese with the peas, artichoke hearts, soup, and a little milk in the pan with the sauteed mushrooms.  Placed the chicken in bottom of glass pan and covered with the stuff from the pan.  Served with chicken flavored rice pilaf and fresh baked french bread.  It was delicious, just wish I had used .5 lbs more chicken tenders.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was totally amazing.  You must use top quality mayonnaise (I always use Hellman's).  I used shaved Parmesan, not the powdered stuff in a plastic shaker bottle. I reduced the mayo by 1/3, and replaced it with sour creme.  I added 2 thinly sliced green onions and 3 strips of crumbled bacon.  Mix the topping up the night before and stored in refrigerator.  The next day, simply top the chicken breasts, and slide it in the oven!  Delicious.  I may try adding a few chopped olives next time.

text:
I listened to other reviews and used marinated artichokes which was needed. I omitted half of the mayonnaise for sour cream and have come to this conclusion... get rid of the mayonnaise all together and use a 50/50 blend of room temp cream cheese and sour cream. I mixed minced garlic cloves in this as well. diced jalepenos would be delicious as well. I rate this 3 stars because it needs to be completely redone for a smooth creamy flavorful result.

text:
Wonderful! I used thinly sliced chicken breasts and covered the entire chicken in the artichoke/mayo mixture for several hours to marinate and tenderize.

I also took the advice of others and used jarred/marinated artichokes. They are more tender and flavorful than canned. 

If you use marinated artichokes, give them a rinse and use less salt than called for. Otherwise, you will have a salty mess on your hands.

text:
I found, for my taste, the mayo flavor overpowered the dish. I liked the idea of the recipe. I entertain a lot, especially when the Green Bay Packers are playing, and make a hot spinach & artichoke dip. I always keep some aside for this dish. I use the same directions for baking it, but use the hot spinach & artichoke dip instead of the mayo based topping. Toss some seasoned bread crumbs on top and it steps this dish up to perfection. There are many easy recipes for the dip. Allrecipe's has the one I use, "Artichoke & Spinach Dip Restaurant Style." The ingredients are staples for me, and takes no time to throw together.

text:
Yum, we liked this chicken.  It is very simple to put together, but is really loaded with flavor.  I didn't have garlic pepper, so I used garlic salt and fresh ground pepper in its place.  The two chicken halves I used were pretty thick so I cut them in to two pieces each.  They took 40 minutes to reach the internal temp of 180°.  Served this with 'Out of the Hat Rice' and 'Airport Bob's Green Beans', both AR recipes.

text:
We LOVED this.  It was really good.  I took the advice of everyone else and used 1/2 mayo and 1/2 sour cream.  To that I added a generous sprinkle of Good Seasons Italian dressing mix, some lemon pepper, two cloves of garlic and the Parmesan and chopped/drained marinated artichoke hearts.  I also added some diced red bell pepper and a couple of shakes of cayenne.

Very lightly salted the chicken and spread the mixture over all.  When there were 5 minutes left in the cooking time I sprinkled with bread crumbs, sprayed with Pam and broiled.

Seriously these were so good.  My mom could not stop exclaiming over it and eating it, and she can be picky.

I had only a 7.5 jar of marinated artichokes, less than 1/2 cup of light mayo, and only two pieces of chicken and a boneless piece of pork loin chop. The result is fabulous - chicken and the pork chop!  I will definitely be making this more often!

text:
Very good, and I made extra "sauce" because I wanted to be sure there was some to add to the Egg Noodles.  Made Broccoli to go with this too.  I added some bacon bits, and Panko Bread Crumbs to the top.  Used Salt, Pepper, and Garlic Powder because I didn't have Garlic Pepper, but I next time I'll skip the Salt.

UPDATE on 8/12/14: I sliced the chicken into strips, seasoned with salt, pepper, and garlic powder.  Placed in greased baking dish, then sprinkled chopped ham lunchmeat all over it.  For the topping I made a little extra including adding sour cream, used regular Artichoke Hearts (not marinated), and added fresh Spinach that needed to be used up.  Spread topping all over chicken/ham and then topped it with Panko.  It was VERY Good!!!  Served with Quinoa.

text:
Bland Bland Bland. I do not understand the tastes of the people on this site. I liked the main ingredients so I thought, let's try it people seem to like it. I added mushrooms cooked in OO and garlic to the mix, marinated artichoke hearts, and 1/2 sour cream 1/2 mayo. I also added way more than pinch(!) of garlic pepper. I tasted it at that point and was afraid of a bland mixture. I added lots of cayenne pepper and couldn't even get a pepper kick with all of that other stuff!

I will finish this dish but I almost do not want to. I think I will need some hot sauce to drown the blandness. Maybe next time I would add seasonings directly to the chicken as well, or marinate it too as the chicken was just lacking flavor. It tasted only OK if I got a bite with some of artichokes as those had some flavor.

Delicious! I read the reviews and made the following changes to the original recipe: I used boneless breasts and thighs (I like dark meat, it has more flavor); coated the chicken in flour, salt and pepper and lightly browned on both sides in EVOO and fresh garlic; used frozen artichoke hearts (a lot less salty); used half mayo/half sour cream mix; sprinkled bread crumbs on top. My daughter raved about it, asked for the recipe :)

text:
This is good comfort food. I subbed in Tzatziki sauce for the mayo and mixed in a little honey too. I used my potato masher to get the artichokes nice and pulpy. I also sprinkled a little shredded asiago on top of each fillet to get a better brown on top than the parm could have done by itself. It comes out very moist and with a pleasingly tart yet mild flavor. This isn't going to beat out Chicken Piccata for my favorite chicken recipe, but I like it a lot and will probably make it again.

text:
Tried this last night with one substitution: used greek yogurt instead of mayo. The result? It worked fairly well. The yogurt did curdle, which sounds gross, but it didn't affect the look or taste of the dish. The dish was slightly more acidic than if it had been mayo, but it was not heavy or gross the way mayo can make you feel after eating in a casserole.

Loved this recipe!  I made the following changes:  I cut the chicken in strips, used 1/2 mayo and 1/2 sour cream, both low fat, used marinated artichokes and added fresh mushrooms. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an excellent recipes- works equally well for a weeknight dinner or for having friends over on the weekend.  Based upon prior reviews, I was concerned about excess liquid, so I used frozen artichokes and let them defrost in a colla Der and then microwaved for 4 minutes.  I alsosubstituted half of the mayonnaise with plain yogurt in order to reduce calories.  Lastly, I added two cloves of garlic to the yogurt/mayonnaise mixture.  We used boneless skinless chicken thighs and it came out great. Next time, I may just use yogurt and forgoe the mayonnaise altogether

I loved this recipe.  I added capers (2 TBSP) and also some mozzarella cheese.  I was low on mayo so added half milk. I think this made the chicken so tender.  I will definitely make this again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is certainly very easy and was well-liked by my husband and son (who is 6, and picky).  For me, it was a bit lacking in complex flavor as far as chicken dishes go.  I think I have issues with it because there's so little pepper and not any other herbs.  I also used parmesan from a can.  I usually use fresh parmigiano-reggiano in Italian dishes and I didn't really care for the taste of the cheaper parm.  And finally, when chicken's not browned, grilled or broiled, you lose that savory "umami" flavor that adds so much to a dish.

userID:

Display Name:
1butterycuppy
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/800493.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Quite good.  I used marinated artichoke hearts and it gave quite a tart flavor to the topping - my kids did not care for this taste.  Next time I may try the un-marinated variety.  I pounded out my chicken breasts to an even thickness and then based on previous reviews, I floured and browned them in olive oil, then sprinkled with paprika.  For the topping, I used 2/3 cup greek plain yogurt (may have also added to the tart flavor) and 1/3 light mayo, added a couple of minced garlic cloves and remember to squeeze out the excess juice in your artichokes.  After topping the chicken breasts with the artichoke mix, I sprinkled a thin layer of panko bread crumbs and drizzled with a teeny bit of olive oil and baked for 20 minutes (because they were thinner and pre-cooked with the browning)...

text:
I don't give 5 stars very often, but this dish is delicious AND very quick and easy.  You can change it up based on what you have available--for instance I didn't have parm, so I used pepper jack.  I've also used feta and left over kalamata olives.  The chicken is VERY moist and tender.  I don't think the mayo needs to be cut with sour cream.  I use olive oil mayo, and it turns out perfect.

bakeRekib

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a good recipe. Maybe 3.5 for flavor (as is) but  definitely a 5 for ease, and probably a 4.5 for versatility. After I made it as is (I feel you should make the recipe before changing & rating) I felt it a bit bland and a bit too much greasy liquid left in the pan. I subbed 1/3c sour cream; used a large clove of fresh garlic, minced; and put some grill marks on the chicken b4 baking for added plate appeal. I served it on a bed of Purple Chard which I left the stems on & lightly steamed in a 1/4" of water and sprinkled w/Kosher salt. The added color and texture was just what it needed! This is a solid recipe i.e. if you keep the measurements the same, you can do endless variations and they will all turn out great!!

LynC

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummy!  4 stars for the recipe as is.   If you have a few extra minutes, make it 5 stars by quickly browning the chicken first (on the stovetop with a little olive oil), reduce the baking time to 20-23 minutes, then broil for the last 2 minutes. Browning the chicken first seals in the juices and broiling adds a nice color.  After cooking, there's a lot of liquid in the pan & I usually just pour most of the excess liquid out.

I did use half sour cream and half mayo as advised by other reviewers, a well as adding some buttered bread crumbs on top and broiling for five minutes, after baking for 35.  The chicken was very moist and tender, but it was just kind of blah.

text:
We liked this. I pounded my chicken thin and sprinkled it with black pepper. I followed another reviewers suggestion of squeezing the artichokes to get the extra water out. I think this did the trick. Otherwise I think there would have been a sloppy mess in the pan. I did part mayo part sour cream like others suggested. I did more mayo than sour cream though because I understand the mayo is necessary for the moistness of the chicken. I put in 1 tea minced garlic. Then I lightly covered the sauced chicken with 4C seasoned bread crumbs. Baked for 30 min. Broiled for 3-5 until brown. I feel this last step is a MUST. Good recipe! Will DEFINITELY make again!!

I took the advice of other reviews; instead of using mayo alone, I used half fat free mayo and half low fat sour cream so the chicken wouldn't be too oily.  I also added garlic powder, italian seasoning, and rosemary (about 1/2 tsp of each) to the mayo/sour cream mix before coating my chicken and it gave it a great flavor.  I also used regular artichoke hearts since that's what I had at the house and the chicken tasted great!  The chicken was so moist!

text:
This is delicious the way it is; however I was really short on time one day and decided to use some asiago artichoke dip from the deli that was sitting in my fridge instead, and it turned out just as well.  All I did was sprinkle a little garlic salt on the chicken, spoon some dip on top, and add a little extra grated Parmesan (took about 3 minutes!) and popped it in the oven. No fuss, no muss, no bother! Great flavour, easy and fast - too bad it isn't lower in fat then I'd make more often. My picky 2 year old likes it too.

text:
This is easy and yummy.  I took the suggestions of using marinated artichoke hearts and 1/2 mayo, 1/2 sour cream.  I made up the mix and let it sit for an hour before putting it on the chicken and in the oven.  It gave the flavors a chance to develop.  I'll make this again but will season the chicken before putting on the topping.  **UPDATE:  I seasoned the chicken with garlic powder and black pepper 24 hours prior to making this.  Turned out muuuuuch better then the first time!  YUM!

Display Name:
Jana Gunn

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2289127.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this last night for company, and everyone loved it!  I had thawed out a whole 3 lb. bag of chicken breasts, so I doubled the artichoke mixture, put it in a 9 x 12 baking dish and cooked it 10 minutes longer than recipe stated.  I didn't have garlic pepper or marinated artichoke hearts like others suggested, so I chopped up regular canned artichoke hearts and mixed in a couple teaspoons of garlic from a jar, some garlic salt, and a good bit of black pepper and let it sit in that for a few hours before I mixed in the other ingredients.  I also used 1 cup of mayo and 1/2 cup of sour cream, (both light) and it worked out great.  I drained and squeezed the artichokes before chopping so I wouldn't have a watery sauce.  Also, I put paprika on top before baking and it was a beautiful color.  Will make again and again!  Thanks for a different twist on chicken, Amanda!

userID:
1955270
Display Name:
newcook
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
17
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was pleasantly surprised how well this turned out. Even my kids (4 and 3) ate it. I followed many of the suggestions, and here's what I did: I used chicken tenderloins and lightly sprinkled both sides with salt, pepper, garlic powder, and onion powder. For the sauce, I used about a 1/2 cup of light mayo, and about 10-12 ounces (eying what's left of my 16-oz carton) of light sour cream. I'm not a big measuring type person, so I sprinkled in more onion powder, garlic powder, cajun seasoning, crushed red pepper, and salt and pepper, all to taste. I also added a handful of frozen, chopped spinach and the jar of drained, marinated artichoke hearts. I pureed all of this to even out the texture for my kids.  Over the chicken I first put a layer of Parmesan and mozzarella cheese till lightly covered. Then I poured the sauce over the chicken and topped with more Parmesan and mozzarella cheese. I baked it as indicated and served with fettuccine noodles and white rolls (for sopping up the rest of the sauce). It's not a very healthy meal, but it was very tasty!
Review:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
THUMBS UP! This recipe came out very very good! I am not a hugely creative cook so I followed some advice from others that I thought sounded good and it worked out great. I used 1/2c reduced fat sour cream and 1/2c lite mayo...I am not a fan of heavy cream sauces so I figured this would work out well and it did! I also put breadcrumbs on the top (which was the best idea I borrowed) and sprinkled paprika as well. I used the marinated artichokes and squeezed the juice out of them, I was amazed as to how much juice came out! I also added fresh pepper and minced two cloves of garlic, but you could have done none or one clove if you don't like garlic too much. And lastly I chopped up some portobello mushrooms...which are good, but not necessary. I served it with linguine. I will make this again :)

text:
Too much mayo - those that said sub or halve with sour cream are right.  This is sort of like having that artichoke dip (usually with spinach) cooked on top of chicken - very good!  I used marinated artichokes (drained) and put an extra can of artichoke hearts in water (drained - squeeze extra water out) all around the edges (just cause I'm an artichoke maniac!).   Everything else was to the letter.  I'm only putting 4 because the mayo was a bit overpowering - wish there was a 4.5.  I hate it when people change the recipe and then rate it - but I will say the big difference was there was too much mayo in the original - that was the only thing from the recipe I didn't like.  My family did say "make it again!"  :)

text:
My husband gave this a 5. I gave it a 3 so it came out a 4. I'm not a fan of parmesan cheese at all. I was hoping everything else would drown out the taste but it didn't. This would be sooo good if I didn't use the parmesan cheese. Next time I will try Mozzarella chesse instead of parmesan. I did take others advice & use 1/2 mayo & 1/2 sour cream. The sauce was to die for. I also took others advise & used the marinated artichokes and I don't think I will use them again. Tasted too much like Italian dressing it was marinated in & I'm not a fan of that either. So next time I make this, I will stick to the recipe but swap the parmesan cheese out with moss. cheese. Thanks so much for the recipe. Those who like the marinated artichokes & parmesan cheese must like real Italian food because that is what it tasted like.

text:
It was very delicious, and it is a good comfort food because of its richness and cheesiness. I followed the recipe, but instead of the garlic pepper I added a bit of garlic powder to the artickoke mix and salt and pepper to the chicken. The chicken came out perfect, very juicy. My tips are that I squeezed out the excess juice from the artichokes, added a bit of olive oil to the bottom of the pan, and added only a pinch of salt or else it comes out salty.

The first time I made this I followed the recipe exactly and it was a huge hit! Everyone loved it.  The second time I diced and browned 6 slices of bacon and sauted 1/2 box of frozen spinach with 1/2 diced onion and added 1 tsp lemon zest.  I also only used 1/2 cup mayo and added 1/2 cup sour cream. I then mixed all of this with the artichokes and cheese and placed on top of chicken cutlets.   This was wonderful!

userID:

Display Name:
Sandra Lou

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe last night, but I found it in a Taste of Home Cookbook.
I used chicken tenders (breasts cut in half length-wise would work well). The thinner, smaller chicken pieces made it faster to cook, more tender, and easier to serve and eat. Also, I used reduced-fat mayo since that's all I ever purchase. I like more garlic flavor in my artichoke dip, so I used about 1/2 tsp of garlic powder, next time I'll up that amount as well.
Mine didn't brown very much and I couldn't broil it since I was using my glass casserole dish. I think baking it on an upper oven rack would have solved that problem.
The biggest surprise was that my artichoke hating family had no idea what they were eating and they LOVED it! DH had 2 servings before he decided to stop before exploding. Served with brown rice and green beans.

Very good recipe!!  Chicken was sooooo tender and delicious.  The only things I did differently was using Hellman's Mayo with canola oil (it tastes just like their regular mayo, only no cholestrol), and I used a big clove of garlic chopped because I didn't have garlic pepper.  Just a tip..the articoke hearts have plenty of sodium in them, so I wouldn't recommend using any salt, only pepper.  This recipe stays in the rotation!!!

text:
This recipe was easy and so flavorful! I had to make a few changes based on what I had on hand...1 pinch garlic powder instead of garlic pepper,a dash of garlic & herb flavor "Mrs. Dash", light mayonnaise, and marinated artichoke hearts. I stirred in 1 teaspoon of the artichoke oil from the jar just to get it to spread easier. I'm glad I did not add any salt, as it would have been way too salty! I also pounded the chicken nice and thin, it cooked fast and was tender.
I will make this again! Thanks so much

text:
Been using this recipe base since 2008! Ive since switched some ingredients around.. I use lemon pepper, powdered garlic and marinated artichokes. 1/2 mayo 1/2 sour cream and I add 1c chopped sautéed spinach and top it with 1/2c Motzerella cheese. I like to prep it in a dish before work so I get home and can throw it in the oven. Sometimes I add fresh basil from the garden. Either way you play with it, this is a fantastic base recipe and has become standard rotation in my house :)

userID:
2693774
Display Name:
YummyTummy
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/131.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This chicken was pretty basic tasting.  I did follow suggestions and cut mayo with some sour cream, it helps cut the fat but not so much for the flavor.  It made it a little bland even for me. My husband loved this dish and said it was even better the next day for lunch..I just wasn't that into it I guess.  I don't think I liked the  Marinated Artichokes I used because I swear they tasted exactly like olives and I am not a fan of them. I would use artichokes that are NOT MARINATED like the recipe says, because they will have the distinct taste of olive oil and olive taste since that is what they are marinated in. I did season the chicken with S&P  and some paprika as was suggested, it did help the chicken.  Also I like to pound the chicken breast out a little bit whenever I bake them, it makes them super moist. Also I found that the Parmesean cheese did not melt that well so I suggest a better melting cheese next time, Mozzarella or maybe some slices of Muenster laid under the mayo/artichoke mix would be delicious.  All in all great recipe to help expose cooks to new flavors and ideas. Thanks!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
Very good!  As others suggested, I did half mayo/half sour cream. I also used 2 cloves of fresh garlic in lieu of garlic pepper.  I also added about 1/4-1/2 tsp. of dried thyme.  My fiance LOVED it.  I loved it too, but by the end thought that it was too rich.  I think toning down the cheese and maybe adding something else to make the topping creamier (maybe just starting the whole thing with a roux, or using some lemon-based sauce) would help make this dish a little more delicate (which was what I was looking for).  But definitely a keeper!

text:
This was great! I only had the small jar of the marinated artichokes, so I decided to chop up the chicken and emptyed out the marinade from the artichoke and used that (plus some salt and lemon pepper) to marinade the chicken pcs for about 5 mins while I got everything else together. I used half sour cream and half mayo plus added a T of minced garlic. I spread that mixture directly over the marinading chioken pcs and then baked for about 15-20 mins. I served with sauteed spinish with garlic  and mushrooms over egg noodles. My boyfriend couldn't stop saying how great it tasted. I would really love the leftovers for breakfast!! lol Thanks for a great recipe!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
So delicious and simple! I've used hints from other reviewers, and used 1/2 mayo (low-fat) and 1/2 sour cream (non-fat). I also use a combination of canned artichokes and marinated ones. My favorite addition to the recipe is about 1/4 cup of sliced black olives. Another trick: if you grill the chicken breasts first, then you can just top them with the artichoke mixture and heat in the microwave. It's just as yummy (and it adds that "cooked chicken color" so the result is not quite so "blond"). This recipe is definitely a keeper.

None
country:
None
text:
This was good!  I used reduced fat mayo and replace half of it with reduced fat sour cream.  I also used freshly grated parmesan cheese and added 3 cloves of minced garlic instead of the garlic pepper.  I used the food processor to chop my artichokes and combine the sauce ingredients.  Next time I think I'll add the artichokes last so they're chunkier.  Also, it took about 1 hour to cook the chicken breasts.  Next time I'll pound them thin and saute in a little EVOO to give them a little extra flavor and color.  Overall, a great dish.  I served with rice.

text:
The taste of this dish was FANTASTIC!  I increased some ingredients (1 cup light mayo and 2 cans artichokes) and also added about 1/2 c sour cream.  The only problem I had was the amount of liquid in the bottom of the pan.  Next time I will not only drain the artichokes, but will gently squeeze them in a paper towel to cut down on the liquid even more.  Either that or try them on a broiler pan.  My kids didn't like artichokes, so they didn't care for it.  But if you like artichoke dip, you'll LOVE this!

country:
None
text:
This is a really delicious and moist way to prepare chicken. I modified the advice of other reviewers and used mostly light sour cream with only about three tablespoons of mayonnaise. I used two small jars of artichoke hearts for a total of 13 ounces. I heeded others' advice and rinsed them off to remove the oil, using a strainer, before incorporating them into the recipe. I also used a package of chicken tenders because I didn't have any chicken breasts on hand. Finally, I forgot to add the lemon pepper, but it was just right in terms of salt.

I made this for dinner last night. It was good. I substituted the mayo w/ 1/2 fat free mayo and 1/2 fat free sour cream. I also used fresh garlic and fresh ground pepper instead of garlic pepper and added a little squeeze of lemon juice.
It's low cal and low fat and has a lot of flavor. I served it w/ white rice.
The chicken did need to be cooked longer than 30 minutes though. I'd say about 40 minutes with 2 small but thick breasts.

text:
Wow!  What a lot of reviews.  These kind of recipes are always worth trying I find.  I used half mayo, fat reduced, and half sour cream with 1 tbsp. flour stirred smoothly into the mixture so it wouldn't curdle and become watery.  I rinsed the artichokes well and gently squeezed out more liquid with my hands (clean!).  Used fresh garlic, fresh basil, freshly grated Parmesan as directed and sprinkled with smoked paprika for colour.  I don't like 'pale' food.  Served a side dish of pasta.  De-lish!  Thank you for this great, easy recipe that is ideal for a family or company dinner.

Yummy with a nice variety of greens as the side!  It was very moist with juices and a bit oily, but at the last 10 minutes removed half the juices/oils.  The last ten minutes really browned the top, as well.  I used crushed garlic/ginger combo.  I, also, used just 1/2 cup of parm cheese.  I will try low-cal mayo next time.  I can't wait for lunch today!

PS: Shred the chicken before hand ... use it as a dip!!  AND the recipe made enough for 6 servings (I fed this to two kids: 12 and 13 if that tells you anything about portions!)

text:
This recipe was well-received and I would definitely make it again. The chicken breasts I had were very thick so I coated them in flour first and browned them in oil before I put them in the oven. I did notice that the artichoke mixture WAS a little thick and gloppy so I will try the sour cream next time to see if that helps. The Parmesan cheese added a nice touch because the topping got all nice and crunchy - really added a nice texture. Very flavorful, can't wait to make it again!

text:
This recipe is really really good!  The chicken was very tender and the topping is great!  I asked my babysitter to put this together for me one night, and by mistake she used the entire package of breasts (8) instead of just 4.  It was still good, so if you have more than 4 breasts you can use them, it's still good.  One thing though... I was confused by "chicken breast halves."   I'm not sure if I was supposed to cut the breasts as they come in the package in half or not.  We didn't, but we did up the baking time to a full hour at 375.  It was still delicious and the breasts, even the big ones, were cooked to perfection.
